Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Blockade-Assisted Entanglement Purification of Noisy Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We introduce a static linear-optical protocol that combines two probabilistic noisy Bell-pair sources with single-emitter photon-blockade nodes to suppress double-pair emissions and distill the target high-fidelity Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9=(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2. By performing a parity check on one photon from each pair via a 50:50 beam splitter and enforcing \u22641-photon inputs through photon-blockade ancillae, specific heralding detection patterns project the remaining photons onto the purified Bell state within the PyTheus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. The resulting single\u2010click detector events yield a fully quantized classifier response targeting photonic qudit state discrimination as a new quantum\u2010metric machine\u2010learning primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Flux\u2010Controlled Chiral Teleportation Routing in a Hermitian Topological Ring\n\nAbstract: We propose a static, linear\u2010optical experiment that implements a chiral teleportation router on a Hermitian one\u2010dimensional periodic lattice of three nodes, injecting a single\u2010photon qubit at node A and performing Bell measurements on edges AB, BC, and CA. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Hybrid-Dimensional Qubit\u2013Qutrit Entanglement Swapping via a Full 2\u00d73 Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in PyTheus a probabilistic protocol that entangles a Rydberg-encoded qubit (mode 0) with a condensate-encoded qutrit (mode 3) by performing a full 2\u00d73 Bell measurement on a shared qubit\u2013qutrit mediator (modes 1&2).  Conditioned on one of the six generalized Bell outcomes, this linear-optics and number-resolving detection scheme heralds the target qubit\u2013qutrit Bell state \u201600\u27e9+ei\u03c6\u201612\u27e9/\u221a2 across the two distinct Hilbert spaces without feedback, hyper-entanglement, or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Each spin is initially entangled with an emitted photon via a coherent light\u2013matter interaction on chip, realizing two independent Bell pairs:\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2081 emits an abstract Bell state between spin-mode 0 and photonic mode 2.\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2082 emits an identical Bell state between spin-mode 1 and photonic mode 3.\nThe two photons (modes 2 & 3) are routed by an integrated waveguide circuit into a linear-optics Bell-state measurement (BSM) block (a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifters). Successful BSM outcomes are heralded by two ancillary detectors (modes 4 & 5). Conditioned on a click in each ancilla detector (post-selection), the two remote spins (nodes 0 & 1) collapse into a maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates photonic-mediated entanglement swapping of matter qubits on chip.\n\nVisualization (modes going top\u2192bottom):\nemitters: [ S\u2081: (0\u21942) ]  [ S\u2082: (1\u21943) ]  \ncircuit: [ waveguide routing 2 & 3 into 50:50 BS + phase shifter network ]  \ndetectors: [spin-readout@0][spin-readout@1][detector@2][detector@3][ancilla@4][ancilla@5]\n\nKey points:\n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward: success is post-selected by ancilla clicks.\n  \u2013 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction enters via the two initial Bell-pair sources.\n  \u2013 Entire Bell-measurement circuit and routing is realized in an integrated photonic waveguide architecture.\n  \u2013 The target is the abstract transformation: two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 post-selected spin\u2013spin Bell pair (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9).\n  \u2013 This protocol can be generalized to multiple nodes (linear repeater chains or networks with star/topologies).\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description: \"On-chip entanglement swapping between two spin qubits via photonic Bell-measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hybrid_spin_swap\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],        # Each block has two ancilla detectors (modes 6,7 for B-branch and modes 8,9 for C-branch). A pair of clicks in either the B-branch detectors or the C-branch detectors heralds successful teleportation to B or C, respectively\u2014but because the split was coherent, the teleportation destination remains in superposition until detection. Two pairs of ancilla detectors (modes 8&9 for R\u2081\u2010branch, 10&11 for R\u2082\u2010branch) herald successful network\u2010coded teleportation events. Successful BSM outcomes are heralded by two ancillary detectors (modes 4 & 5). Too close to earlier spin\u2013photon swap proposals.\n    2. Basically two sequential swaps\u2014interesting but expected.\n    3. Purification is genuinely new for Pytheus: it implements a network transformation beyond swap/teleport, uses only probabilistic pair sources and linear optics, no dynamic feedback, and can be generalized to multiple rounds.\n  Step 3: Choose idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty: No previous Pytheus target performs entanglement purification on coherent\u2010light\u2010matter qubit memories via an on\u2010chip parity\u2010check circuit. This extends network protocols into error\u2010mitigation.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can encode two abstract Bell\u2010pair sources (spin\u2013photon), a passive integrated beam\u2010splitter parity network on the two photons, and two ancilla detectors for post\u2010selection. No cavities or feed\u2010forward are needed.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014an integrated\u2010photonic entanglement\u2010purification primitive for two spin qubits, using coherent light\u2013matter interfaces and linear optics:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label two stationary spin\u2010qubit nodes on chip: Q\u2081 (mode 0) and Q\u2082 (mode 1). Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each generate a (noisy) abstract Bell pair:\n \u2022 S\u2081 produces entanglement between spin 0 and photon mode 2.  \n \u2022 S\u2082 produces entanglement between spin 1 and photon mode 3.  \n\nThese two raw spin\u2013photon Bell pairs suffer dephasing or imperfect fidelity. We wish to purify them into a single higher\u2010fidelity spin\u2013spin Bell pair on nodes 0&1. To do so, we interfere the two photons (modes 2,3) in an integrated parity\u2010check circuit: a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifter network that effectively implements a photonic parity measurement. Two number\u2010resolving detectors (modes 4 & 5) herald a successful even\u2010parity outcome. Conditioned on one click in each detector (post\u2010selection), the remaining spins collapse into a purified Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates on\u2010chip entanglement purification of matter qubit memories.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21942)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21943)]  \nparity\u2010circuit:  [BS(2,3) + phase network]  \ndetectors:   [spin-read@0][spin-read@1][anc@4][anc@5]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"On-chip entanglement purification of two spin qubits via photonic parity check\",\n  foldername          : \"spin_purification_chip\",\n  edges_tried         : 25,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 2,               # detectors 4 & 5\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 10,\n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],     # purified spin pair on nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [0,1],\n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [4,5],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2013 Cascaded purification: chain multiple rounds by feeding in additional raw pairs.  \n \u2013 Multipartite purification: extend to three or more spins via multi-photon parity checks.  \n \u2013 Forms a building block for on-chip error mitigation in scalable photonic\u2013matter quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to known entanglement purification protocols (including on-chip qutrit purification and passive Bell-filter networks) and offers no fundamentally new element. On\u2010chip entanglement swapping of two spin qubits via a linear\u2010optics Bell analyzer (spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 spin\u2013spin Bell).\n  2. Chained teleportation A\u2192B\u2192C on chip: two sequential, post\u2010selected Bell measurements transferring a spin\u2010qubit along a repeater link.\n  3. A quantum\u2010switch for entanglement\u2010swapping: superpose two different orders of Bell\u2010measurements on a single integrated circuit, heralded by post\u2010selected detection.\nStep 2: Assessment:\n  1. Too close to existing swap proposals.\n  2. Just two swaps in series\u2014expected.\n  3. The quantum\u2010switch is genuinely new: it realizes indefinite causal order of two swapping channels in a single static photonic network, using only pair sources, beam splitters, and detectors\u2014no feedback or cavities.\nStep 3: I choose idea (3).\nStep 4: Novelty: No prior Pytheus target implements a quantum\u2010switch of two entanglement\u2010swapping channels; this elevates a static integrated\u2010optics circuit into a higher\u2010order quantum supermap, demonstrating indefinite causal order in a quantum\u2010network primitive.\nStep 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can encode three coherent light\u2013matter Bell\u2010pair sources, an on\u2010chip Mach\u2013Zehnder\u2013like splitter network that routes photonic modes through two Bell analyzers in superposition, and number\u2010resolving ancilla detectors for post\u2010selection. No dynamic control is needed\u2014just static linear optics and heralded detection.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014an on\u2010chip quantum\u2010switch for entanglement\u2010swapping, combining coherent light\u2013matter Bell\u2010pair sources with an integrated photonic supermap:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label three on\u2010chip spin\u2010qubit nodes: Control (0), A (1), C (2). Three coherent light\u2013matter interfaces produce abstract Bell pairs:\n \u2022 S\u2080 entangles Control(0) \u2194 photon p\u2080  \n \u2022 S\u2081 entangles A(1) \u2194 photon p\u2081  \n \u2022 S\u2082 entangles C(2) \u2194 photon p\u2082  \n\nGoal: entangle A and C via two successive Bell\u2010measurements on the photons, but with the order of those two measurements placed in quantum superposition\u2014i.e., realize a \u201cquantum switch\u201d of two swapping channels.  \n\nIntegrated circuit:\n \u2022 Photonic modes p\u2081 and p\u2082 pass through a 50:50 integrated splitter network controlled by p\u2080 (the control photon).  \n \u2022 Depending on the path in the splitter, p\u2081 first meets p\u2082 in Bell\u2010analyzer Module \u03b1 then Module \u03b2, or vice versa; because p\u2080 is in a superposition, the ordering of \u03b1 and \u03b2 is coherently superposed.  \n \u2022 Each Bell\u2010module is a beam splitter + phase\u2010shifter block with two ancilla detectors: Module \u03b1 \u2192 detectors d\u2083,d\u2084; Module \u03b2 \u2192 detectors d\u2085,d\u2086.  \n\nPost\u2010selection:\n \u2022 A click in one detector pair of \u03b1 and one of \u03b2 heralds a successful \u201cswitch\u2010ed\u201d entanglement\u2010swap.\n \u2022 Conditioned on these four clicks, spins A and C collapse into a Bell pair whose creation process had no definite order. Control qubit 0 remains entangled with which order \u201chappened,\u201d realizing the quantum\u2010switch resource state.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:   [S\u2080:(0\u2194p\u2080)]  [S\u2081:(1\u2194p\u2081)]  [S\u2082:(2\u2194p\u2082)]  \ncircuit:    [p\u2081,p\u2082,p\u2080 \u2192 integrated MZI\u2013style split & two Bell\u2010modules \u03b1,\u03b2]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2013read@0][spin\u2013read@1][spin\u2013read@2][d\u2083][d\u2084][d\u2085][d\u2086]\n\nKey points:\n \u2022 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction enters via the three Bell\u2010pair sources.  \n \u2022 Integrated photonic circuit implements a passive quantum switch\u2014indefinite order of two Bell\u2010measurements.  \n \u2022 Purely post-selected, no dynamic feedback.  \n \u2022 The abstract target is not a static many-qubit state, but the higher-order transformation (\u201csupermap\u201d) that superposes two network channels.  \n \u2022 This primitive can be generalized to superpositions of N different network topologies (e.g. parallel vs. series links) and opens a new class of on-chip quantum\u2010network operations beyond fixed paths.  \n\nThis proposal merges coherent spin\u2013photon interfaces with on-chip indefinite\u2010order photonic routing, offering a first demonstration of a quantum switch in a quantum\u2010network context."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a fully specified target for Pytheus\u2014an on-chip, post-selected entanglement swap between two matter qubits mediated by an integrated photonic Bell-state analyzer.\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider two stationary spin qubits (e.g. quantum-dot exciton levels) on an integrated photonic chip, labelled nodes 0 and 1. Each spin is initially entangled with an emitted photon via a coherent light\u2013matter interaction on chip, realizing two independent Bell pairs:\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2081 emits an abstract Bell state between spin-mode 0 and photonic mode 2.\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2082 emits an identical Bell state between spin-mode 1 and photonic mode 3.\nThe two photons (modes 2 & 3) are routed by an integrated waveguide circuit into a linear-optics Bell-state measurement (BSM) block (a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifters). Successful BSM outcomes are heralded by two ancillary detectors (modes 4 & 5). Conditioned on a click in each ancilla detector (post-selection), the two remote spins (nodes 0 & 1) collapse into a maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates photonic-mediated entanglement swapping of matter qubits on chip.\n\nVisualization (modes going top\u2192bottom):\nemitters: [ S\u2081: (0\u21942) ]  [ S\u2082: (1\u21943) ]  \ncircuit: [ waveguide routing 2 & 3 into 50:50 BS + phase shifter network ]  \ndetectors: [spin-readout@0][spin-readout@1][detector@2][detector@3][ancilla@4][ancilla@5]\n\nKey points:\n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward: success is post-selected by ancilla clicks.\n  \u2013 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction enters via the two initial Bell-pair sources.\n  \u2013 Entire Bell-measurement circuit and routing is realized in an integrated photonic waveguide architecture.\n  \u2013 The target is the abstract transformation: two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 post-selected spin\u2013spin Bell pair (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9).\n  \u2013 This protocol can be generalized to multiple nodes (linear repeater chains or networks with star/topologies).\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description: \"On-chip entanglement swapping between two spin qubits via photonic Bell-measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hybrid_spin_swap\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],        # spin nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes: [],                       # pair sources define inputs\n  out_nodes: [0,1],\n  heralding_out: null,\n  single_emitters: [],                # abstract pair sources instead\n  amplitudes: [],\n  removed_connections: [],            # allow all routing\n  anc_detectors: [4,5],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal essentially describes a standard entanglement\u2010swapping protocol\u2014two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs followed by a photonic Bell measurement yielding a spin\u2013spin Bell pair\u2014but merely implemented in an on\u2010chip waveguide circuit. Such spin\u2013photon mediated entanglement swapping has already been demonstrated in NV centers, quantum dots, and other platforms (e.g. Moehring et al. Nature 2007; Bernien et al. Nature 2013), and integrated photonic Bell analyzers are well\u2010explored. There is no new foundational feature, multi-node network effect, or higher-dimensional twist that would elevate this to PRL novelty.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too close to existing spin\u2013photon entanglement-swapping experiments and on-chip Bell analyzers. To be novel at the PRL level, you would need to introduce a genuinely new element\u2014e.g. an indefinite\u2010order swap, a heralded multi-qubit fusion primitive that cannot be reduced to standard swapping, or integration of nonclassical ancilla conservation that goes beyond straightforward photonic routing.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target configuration\u2014an integrated \u201cquantum\u2010router\u201d that teleports a spin\u2010qubit from node A to B or C in coherent superposition, heralded by post-selected photonic detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label three stationary spin qubits on chip: A (mode 0), B (mode 1), C (mode 2). Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each produce an abstract Bell pair:\n  \u2022 S\u2081: entangles spin A (0) with photonic mode 3.  \n  \u2022 S\u2082: entangles spin B (1) with photonic mode 4.  \n  \u2022 S\u2083: entangles spin C (2) with photonic mode 5.  \n\nWe wish to teleport an arbitrary input state |\u03c8\u27e9 on spin A to either B or C, but in a controlled superposition. We build an integrated photonic circuit that routes mode 3 equally into two Bell\u2010measurement blocks:\n  \u2013 Block 1 jointly measures modes (3 & 4) to teleport to B.\n  \u2013 Block 2 jointly measures modes (3 & 5) to teleport to C.\n\nA 50:50 directional coupler splits mode 3 into paths to both blocks; the two Bell\u2010analyzers are realized with beam splitters and phase shifters on chip. Each block has two ancilla detectors (modes 6,7 for B-branch and modes 8,9 for C-branch). A pair of clicks in either the B-branch detectors or the C-branch detectors heralds successful teleportation to B or C, respectively\u2014but because the split was coherent, the teleportation destination remains in superposition until detection. The final abstract mapping is:\n\n  |\u03c8\u27e9_A \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{B4} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{C5}\n    \u2192 ( |\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{6,7} + |\u03c8\u27e9_C\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{8,9} )\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21943)]  [S\u2082:(1\u21944)]  [S\u2083:(2\u21945)]  \ncircuit:    [split 3 \u2192 path to Bell-analyzer(3,4) + Bell-analyzer(3,5)]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][anc6][anc7][anc8][anc9]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description       : \"On\u2010chip superposition\u2010of\u2010destinations quantum router via post\u2010selected teleportation\",\n  foldername        : \"quantum_router_teleport\",\n  edges_tried       : 30,\n  ftol              : 1e-06,\n  loss_func         : \"cr\",\n  num_anc           : 4,            # detectors 6,7,8,9\n  optimizer         : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples           : 12,\n  target_quantum    : [\"0B\",\"1B\",\"0C\",\"1C\"], # abstract mapping onto spin B or C\n  in_nodes          : [],\n  out_nodes         : [1,2,6,7,8,9], \n  single_emitters   : [],\n  amplitudes        : [],\n  removed_connections: [],          # allow all beam\u2010splitter couplings\n  anc_detectors     : [6,7,8,9],\n  number_resolving  : true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Can be extended to N output nodes by splitting into N Bell blocks.  \n  \u2013 Forms a building block for photonic\u2010mediated quantum networks on a chip: coherent routing primitives beyond fixed\u2010path swapping.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a spin\u2010qubit version of the \u201cdual\u2010destination teleportation switch\u201d already in the ensemble list (see \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\u201d). It merely replaces flying photonic inputs by matter\u2010spin emitters but retains the same coherent splitting into two Bell\u2010measurements with post\u2010selection. There is no new network primitive, higher\u2010dimensional generalization, or causally nontrivial ordering that would push it beyond standard teleportation routing.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s dual\u2010destination teleportation switch in matter\u2010photonic form without adding a genuinely new element. To be novel enough for PRL, introduce a fundamentally different routing primitive (e.g. indefinite causal order, multi\u2010target fusion, or a new nonlocal supermap) rather than straightforward coherent path\u2010splitting and Bell measurements.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target\u2014an integrated\u2010photonic \u201cquantum router\u201d that teleports a spin\u2010qubit |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 to nodes B or C in coherent superposition, heralded by post\u2010selected photonic detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label three stationary qubit nodes on chip: A (mode 0), B (mode 1), C (mode 2). Three coherent light\u2013matter interfaces produce three abstract Bell pairs:\n  \u2022 S\u2081: entangles qubit A (0) with photonic mode 3.  \n  \u2022 S\u2082: entangles qubit B (1) with photonic mode 4.  \n  \u2022 S\u2083: entangles qubit C (2) with photonic mode 5.  \n\nWe wish to teleport an unknown state |\u03c8\u27e9 from A into a coherent superposition of B and C. Photonic mode 3 is passed through an integrated 50:50 splitter that routes it equally into two Bell\u2010analyzer blocks:\n  \u2013 Block B: joint Bell measurement on modes (3\u2081,4) to teleport to B, heralded by clicks in ancilla detectors 6 & 7.\n  \u2013 Block C: joint Bell measurement on modes (3\u2082,5) to teleport to C, heralded by clicks in ancilla detectors 8 & 9.\n\nBecause the splitter acts coherently, a successful pair of clicks in {6,7} vs. {8,9} projects the final state to |\u03c8\u27e9 at B or at C\u2014but before detection the destination is in superposition. The overall abstract post\u2010selected mapping is:\n\n  |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080 \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{1,4} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{2,5}\n    \u2192 ( |\u03c8\u27e9\u2081 \u2297 |clicks\u27e9_{6,7} + |\u03c8\u27e9\u2082 \u2297 |clicks\u27e9_{8,9} ).\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21943)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21944)]   [S\u2083:(2\u21945)]  \ncircuit:    [split 3 \u2192 two Bell blocks on (3,4) and (3,5)]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][anc6][anc7][anc8][anc9]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"Quantum\u2010router: coherent superposition teleportation A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  foldername          : \"quantum_router_teleport\",\n  edges_tried         : 30,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 4,             # ancillas 6,7,8,9\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 12,\n  target_quantum      : [\"\u03c8@1+\u03c8@2\"],   # abstract superposition target on modes 1&2 conditioned on ancillas\n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [1,2],  \n  heralding_out       : null,\n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],  \n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [6,7,8,9],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N possible destinations by splitting into N Bell\u2010analyzers.  \n  \u2013 Forms a new primitive for coherent routing in integrated photonic quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This on\u2010chip spin\u2010qubit router is essentially the same coherent dual\u2010destination teleportation switch already in the ensemble (\u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\u201d), merely replacing flying photonic inputs by matter emitters. Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each generate a (noisy) abstract Bell pair:\n \u2022 S\u2081 produces entanglement between spin 0 and photon mode 2.  \n \u2022 S\u2082 produces entanglement between spin 1 and photon mode 3.  \n\nThese two raw spin\u2013photon Bell pairs suffer dephasing or imperfect fidelity. We wish to purify them into a single higher\u2010fidelity spin\u2013spin Bell pair on nodes 0&1. To do so, we interfere the two photons (modes 2,3) in an integrated parity\u2010check circuit: a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifter network that effectively implements a photonic parity measurement. Two number\u2010resolving detectors (modes 4 & 5) herald a successful even\u2010parity outcome. Conditioned on one click in each detector (post\u2010selection), the remaining spins collapse into a purified Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. The integrated photonic circuit implements the butterfly network coding: it combines photons 4 & 5 on a 50:50 coupler, splits outputs into two arms, and then each arm interferes with photon 6 or 7 in a Bell\u2010measurement block. Two pairs of ancilla detectors (modes 8&9 for R\u2081\u2010branch, 10&11 for R\u2082\u2010branch) herald successful network\u2010coded teleportation events. Three coherent light\u2013matter interfaces produce abstract Bell pairs:\n \u2022 S\u2080 entangles Control(0) \u2194 photon p\u2080  \n \u2022 S\u2081 entangles A(1) \u2194 photon p\u2081  \n \u2022 S\u2082 entangles C(2) \u2194 photon p\u2082  \n\nGoal: entangle A and C via two successive Bell\u2010measurements on the photons, but with the order of those two measurements placed in quantum superposition\u2014i.e., realize a \u201cquantum switch\u201d of two swapping channels.  \n\nIntegrated circuit:\n \u2022 Photonic modes p\u2081 and p\u2082 pass through a 50:50 integrated splitter network controlled by p\u2080 (the control photon).  \n \u2022 Depending on the path in the splitter, p\u2081 first meets p\u2082 in Bell\u2010analyzer Module \u03b1 then Module \u03b2, or vice versa; because p\u2080 is in a superposition, the ordering of \u03b1 and \u03b2 is coherently superposed.  \n \u2022 Each Bell\u2010module is a beam splitter + phase\u2010shifter block with two ancilla detectors: Module \u03b1 \u2192 detectors d\u2083,d\u2084; Module \u03b2 \u2192 detectors d\u2085,d\u2086.  \n\nPost\u2010selection:\n \u2022 A click in one detector pair of \u03b1 and one of \u03b2 heralds a successful \u201cswitch\u2010ed\u201d entanglement\u2010swap.\n \u2022 Conditioned on these four clicks, spins A and C collapse into a Bell pair whose creation process had no definite order.     "output": "Thought: The proposed on\u2010chip quantum\u2010switch superposing two Bell\u2010measurement orders for entanglement swapping directly mirrors the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch\u201d already in the ensemble list (\u201cImplementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\u201d). It offers no new twist beyond replacing flying photons with spin\u2013photon interfaces.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is effectively identical to the ensemble\u2019s entanglement-switch quantum switch proposal. To achieve true novelty, you must introduce a fundamentally different resource or transformation (e.g. higher-order supermaps beyond two-step switches, novel causal structures, or multi-party indefinite ordering) that cannot be reduced to the known quantum-switch of two swap channels."

    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Thermalization slowing down of weakly nonintegrable quantum spin\n  dynamics\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: New Aspects of Optical Coherence and their Potential for Quantum\n  Technologies\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Scalable entanglement certification via quantum communication\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. Each spin is initially entangled with an emitted photon via a coherent light\u2013matter interaction on chip, realizing two independent Bell pairs:\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2081 emits an abstract Bell state between spin-mode 0 and photonic mode 2.\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2082 emits an identical Bell state between spin-mode 1 and photonic mode 3.\nThe two photons (modes 2 & 3) are routed by an integrated waveguide circuit into a linear-optics Bell-state measurement (BSM) block (a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifters). Successful BSM outcomes are heralded by two ancillary detectors (modes 4 & 5). Conditioned on a click in each ancilla detector (post-selection), the two remote spins (nodes 0 & 1) collapse into a maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates photonic-mediated entanglement swapping of matter qubits on chip.\n\nVisualization (modes going top\u2192bottom):\nemitters: [ S\u2081: (0\u21942) ]  [ S\u2082: (1\u21943) ]  \ncircuit: [ waveguide routing 2 & 3 into 50:50 BS + phase shifter network ]  \ndetectors: [spin-readout@0][spin-readout@1][detector@2][detector@3][ancilla@4][ancilla@5]\n\nKey points:\n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward: success is post-selected by ancilla clicks.\n  \u2013 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction enters via the two initial Bell-pair sources.\n  \u2013 Entire Bell-measurement circuit and routing is realized in an integrated photonic waveguide architecture.\n  \u2013 The target is the abstract transformation: two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 post-selected spin\u2013spin Bell pair (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9).\n  \u2013 This protocol can be generalized to multiple nodes (linear repeater chains or networks with star/topologies).\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description: \"On-chip entanglement swapping between two spin qubits via photonic Bell-measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hybrid_spin_swap\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],        # spin nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes: [],                       # pair sources define inputs\n  out_nodes: [0,1],\n  heralding_out: null,\n  single_emitters: [],                # abstract pair sources instead\n  amplitudes: [],\n  removed_connections: [],            # allow all routing\n  anc_detectors: [4,5],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to existing spin\u2013photon entanglement-swapping experiments and on-chip Bell analyzers. On\u2010chip entanglement swapping of two quantum\u2010dot spins via an integrated linear\u2010optics Bell\u2010analyzer (spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 spin\u2013spin Bell).\n    2. A two\u2010node repeater teleportation segment: teleport a spin\u2010qubit\u2019s state from node A to node C via an intermediate spin memory B, all on chip, using two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs and chained post-selected Bell measurements.\n    3. A \u201cquantum router\u201d that teleports a spin\u2010qubit\u2019s state from A to either B or C, but in a coherent superposition of destinations, by using an on\u2010chip photonic network that splits the Bell\u2010measurement in two branches and recombines them\u2014no feedback, purely post-selected.\n  Step 2: Assess novelty and Pytheus feasibility:\n    1. Too close to existing hybrid swap protocols (and prior photonic Bell analyzers).\n    2. Essentially a chained swap; interesting but conceptually expected.\n    3. Superposition\u2010of\u2010teleportation\u2010routes \u201cquantum router\u201d is genuinely new: it is not mere state generation but a novel network transformation, requires no dynamic control, uses only pair sources, beamsplitters, and heralding.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no prior Pytheus target implements teleportation with coherent superposition of the teleportation destination\u2014it elevates a static swap network into a true quantum\u2010routing primitive.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus since we can encode:\n    \u2022 Two spin\u2013photon Bell\u2010pair sources on chip (coherent light\u2013matter interfaces).  \n    \u2022 A static linear\u2010optics circuit that splits the \u201cBell\u2010measurement\u201d arm into two identical analyzers (one coupling to node B\u2019s ancilla photon, one to C\u2019s).  \n    \u2022 Post\u2010selected ancilla detectors heralding a successful teleportation, with no feed\u2010forward needed.  \n    \u2022 Abstract qubit encoding so Pytheus finds beam splitter phases and coupling to realize the target mapping.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target configuration\u2014an integrated \u201cquantum\u2010router\u201d that teleports a spin\u2010qubit from node A to B or C in coherent superposition, heralded by post-selected photonic detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label three stationary spin qubits on chip: A (mode 0), B (mode 1), C (mode 2). Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each produce an abstract Bell pair:\n  \u2022 S\u2081: entangles spin A (0) with photonic mode 3.  \n  \u2022 S\u2082: entangles spin B (1) with photonic mode 4.  \n  \u2022 S\u2083: entangles spin C (2) with photonic mode 5.  \n\nWe wish to teleport an arbitrary input state |\u03c8\u27e9 on spin A to either B or C, but in a controlled superposition. We build an integrated photonic circuit that routes mode 3 equally into two Bell\u2010measurement blocks:\n  \u2013 Block 1 jointly measures modes (3 & 4) to teleport to B.\n  \u2013 Block 2 jointly measures modes (3 & 5) to teleport to C.\n\nA 50:50 directional coupler splits mode 3 into paths to both blocks; the two Bell\u2010analyzers are realized with beam splitters and phase shifters on chip. Each block has two ancilla detectors (modes 6,7 for B-branch and modes 8,9 for C-branch). A pair of clicks in either the B-branch detectors or the C-branch detectors heralds successful teleportation to B or C, respectively\u2014but because the split was coherent, the teleportation destination remains in superposition until detection. The final abstract mapping is:\n\n  |\u03c8\u27e9_A \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{B4} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{C5}\n    \u2192 ( |\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{6,7} + |\u03c8\u27e9_C\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{8,9} )\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21943)]  [S\u2082:(1\u21944)]  [S\u2083:(2\u21945)]  \ncircuit:    [split 3 \u2192 path to Bell-analyzer(3,4) + Bell-analyzer(3,5)]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][anc6][anc7][anc8][anc9]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description       : \"On\u2010chip superposition\u2010of\u2010destinations quantum router via post\u2010selected teleportation\",\n  foldername        : \"quantum_router_teleport\",\n  edges_tried       : 30,\n  ftol              : 1e-06,\n  loss_func         : \"cr\",\n  num_anc           : 4,            # detectors 6,7,8,9\n  optimizer         : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples           : 12,\n  target_quantum    : [\"0B\",\"1B\",\"0C\",\"1C\"], # abstract mapping onto spin B or C\n  in_nodes          : [],\n  out_nodes         : [1,2,6,7,8,9], \n  single_emitters   : [],\n  amplitudes        : [],\n  removed_connections: [],          # allow all beam\u2010splitter couplings\n  anc_detectors     : [6,7,8,9],\n  number_resolving  : true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Can be extended to N output nodes by splitting into N Bell blocks.  \n  \u2013 Forms a building block for photonic\u2010mediated quantum networks on a chip: coherent routing primitives beyond fixed\u2010path swapping.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s dual\u2010destination teleportation switch in matter\u2010photonic form without adding a genuinely new element. We wish to purify them into a single higher\u2010fidelity spin\u2013spin Bell pair on nodes 0&1. To do so, we interfere the two photons (modes 2,3) in an integrated parity\u2010check circuit: a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifter network that effectively implements a photonic parity measurement. Two number\u2010resolving detectors (modes 4 & 5) herald a successful even\u2010parity outcome. Conditioned on one click in each detector (post\u2010selection), the remaining spins collapse into a purified Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates on\u2010chip entanglement purification of matter qubit memories.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21942)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21943)]  \nparity\u2010circuit:  [BS(2,3) + phase network]  \ndetectors:   [spin-read@0][spin-read@1][anc@4][anc@5]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"On-chip entanglement purification of two spin qubits via photonic parity check\",\n  foldername          : \"spin_purification_chip\",\n  edges_tried         : 25,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 2,               # detectors 4 & 5\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 10,\n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],     # purified spin pair on nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [0,1],\n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [4,5],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2013 Cascaded purification: chain multiple rounds by feeding in additional raw pairs.  \n \u2013 Multipartite purification: extend to three or more spins via multi-photon parity checks.  \n \u2013 Forms a building block for on-chip error mitigation in scalable photonic\u2013matter quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to known entanglement purification protocols (including on-chip qutrit purification and passive Bell-filter networks) and offers no fundamentally new element.     "output": "Here is a novel Pytheus-compatible target\u2014an on-chip, coherent multi-path quantum-repeater teleportation that sends an unknown qubit from node A to node D along two repeater chains (A\u2192B\u2192D and A\u2192C\u2192D) in quantum superposition, using only static linear optics, probabilistic Bell-pair sources (coherent light\u2013matter interfaces), and post-selected detection.\n\nExplanation  \nWe label four stationary \u201cmatter\u201d qubit nodes on chip:  \n \u2022 A (mode 0) \u2013 the input qubit |\u03c8\u27e9  \n \u2022 B (mode 1) \u2013 first repeater branch  \n \u2022 C (mode 2) \u2013 second repeater branch  \n \u2022 D (mode 3) \u2013 the target output  \n\nSix coherent light\u2013matter Bell-pair sources create abstract Bell pairs:  \n \u2022 S\u2081 emits |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between 0\u21944 (A\u2013photon)  \n \u2022 S\u2082 emits |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between 1\u21945 (B\u2013photon)  \n \u2022 S\u2083 emits |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between 2\u21946 (C\u2013photon)  \n \u2022 S\u2084 emits |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between 3\u21947 (D\u2013photon)  \n \u2022 S\u2085 emits |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between 1\u21948 (B\u2013photon for step 2)  \n \u2022 S\u2086 emits |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between 2\u21949 (C\u2013photon for step 2)  \n\nOur goal is to teleport |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080 to qubit 3, but coherently using both B and C repeater paths. The static photonic circuit:\n\n1. 50:50 splitter on mode 4 \u2192 creates 4a & 4b.  \n2. Bell-measurement block M_B on (4a,5) with ancilla detectors 10,11 (A\u2192B hop).  \n3. Bell-measurement block M_C on (4b,6) with ancilla detectors 12,13 (A\u2192C hop).  \n\nAfter these two blocks, the state |\u03c8\u27e9 is transferred (up to Pauli byproducts) onto either qubit 1 or qubit 2, but in a coherent superposition because mode 4 was split.\n\n4. 50:50 splitter on mode 7 \u2192 creates 7a & 7b.  \n5. Bell-measurement block M_{B\u2192D} on (8,7a) with ancilla detectors 14,15 (B\u2192D hop).  \n6. Bell-measurement block M_{C\u2192D} on (9,7b) with ancilla detectors 16,17 (C\u2192D hop).  \n\nPost\u2013selecting on exactly one click pair in {10,11}, one in {12,13}, one in {14,15}, and one in {16,17} yields a heralded teleportation of |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080 onto qubit 3. Because both the first-hop splitter and second-hop splitter act coherently, the teleportation channel is effectively the superposition of the two repeater chains. No feed-forward is required\u2014just passive optics and post-selection.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):  \nemitters: [S\u2081: (0\u21944)] [S\u2082: (1\u21945)] [S\u2083: (2\u21946)] [S\u2084: (3\u21947)] [S\u2085: (1\u21948)] [S\u2086: (2\u21949)]  \ncircuit:  \n\u2003\u2013 Split 4 \u2192 Bell M_B(4a,5) + Bell M_C(4b,6)  \n\u2003\u2013 Split 7 \u2192 Bell M_{B\u2192D}(8,7a) + Bell M_{C\u2192D}(9,7b)  \ndetectors: [spin-read@0][\u00b7\u2026\u00b7][spin-read@3][anc10][anc11][\u2026][anc17]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config  \n{  \n  description         : \"Coherent multi-path teleportation A\u2192D via on-chip B,C repeaters\",  \n  foldername          : \"coherent_multi_path_teleport\",  \n  edges_tried         : 30,  \n  ftol                : 1e-06,  \n  loss_func           : \"cr\",  \n  num_anc             : 8,              # detectors 10\u201317  \n  num_pre             : 1,  \n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  samples             : 12,  \n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],    # teleportation mapping 0\u21923  \n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [3],  \n  heralding_out       : null,  \n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],  \n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [10,11,12,13,14,15,16,17],  \n  number_resolving    : true  \n}\n\nWhy this is novel  \n\u2013 No existing Pytheus target implements teleportation via two parallel repeater chains in coherent superposition.  \n\u2013 It elevates a standard repeater segment into a genuine network-interference primitive\u2014\u201cquantum multiplexing\u201d of teleportation channels.  \n\u2013 It combines on-chip coherent light\u2013matter pair sources with integrated splitters and Bell analyzers into a higher-order network transformation, not mere state generation.\n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible in Pytheus  \n\u2013 All sources are abstract Bell-pair sources\u2014it doesn\u2019t matter if they come from quantum dots or SPDC.  \n\u2013 The entire circuit uses passive beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors\u2014exactly the toolkit Pytheus optimizes over.  \n\u2013 No dynamic feedback or cavities are required\u2014only post-selected heralding via ancilla clicks.  \n\u2013 The idea generalizes: increase the number of parallel paths or hops, merge more channels, or build network multiplexers for future integrated quantum\u2010internet nodes."

Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. Successful BSM outcomes are heralded by two ancillary detectors (modes 4 & 5).
