Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each produce an abstract Bell pair:\n  \u2022 S\u2081: entangles spin A (0) with photonic mode 3.  \n  \u2022 S\u2082: entangles spin B (1) with photonic mode 4.  \n  \u2022 S\u2083: entangles spin C (2) with photonic mode 5.  \n\nWe wish to teleport an arbitrary input state |\u03c8\u27e9 on spin A to either B or C, but in a controlled superposition. We build an integrated photonic circuit that routes mode 3 equally into two Bell\u2010measurement blocks:\n  \u2013 Block 1 jointly measures modes (3 & 4) to teleport to B.\n  \u2013 Block 2 jointly measures modes (3 & 5) to teleport to C.\n\nA 50:50 directional coupler splits mode 3 into paths to both blocks; the two Bell\u2010analyzers are realized with beam splitters and phase shifters on chip. Each block has two ancilla detectors (modes 6,7 for B-branch and modes 8,9 for C-branch). A pair of clicks in either the B-branch detectors or the C-branch detectors heralds successful teleportation to B or C, respectively\u2014but because the split was coherent, the teleportation destination remains in superposition until detection. The final abstract mapping is:\n\n  |\u03c8\u27e9_A \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{B4} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{C5}\n    \u2192 ( |\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{6,7} + |\u03c8\u27e9_C\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{8,9} )\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21943)]  [S\u2082:(1\u21944)]  [S\u2083:(2\u21945)]  \ncircuit:    [split 3 \u2192 path to Bell-analyzer(3,4) + Bell-analyzer(3,5)]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][anc6][anc7][anc8][anc9]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description       : \"On\u2010chip superposition\u2010of\u2010destinations quantum router via post\u2010selected teleportation\",\n  foldername        : \"quantum_router_teleport\",\n  edges_tried       : 30,\n  ftol              : 1e-06,\n  loss_func         : \"cr\",\n  num_anc           : 4,            # detectors 6,7,8,9\n  optimizer         : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples           : 12,\n  target_quantum    : [\"0B\",\"1B\",\"0C\",\"1C\"], # abstract mapping onto spin B or C\n  in_nodes          : [],\n  out_nodes         : [1,2,6,7,8,9], \n  single_emitters   : [],\n  amplitudes        : [],\n  removed_connections: [],          # allow all beam\u2010splitter couplings\n  anc_detectors     : [6,7,8,9],\n  number_resolving  : true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Can be extended to N output nodes by splitting into N Bell blocks.  \n  \u2013 Forms a building block for photonic\u2010mediated quantum networks on a chip: coherent routing primitives beyond fixed\u2010path swapping.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s dual\u2010destination teleportation switch in matter\u2010photonic form without adding a genuinely new element. On\u2010chip entanglement swapping of two quantum\u2010dot spin qubits via a linear\u2010optics Bell\u2010analyzer (spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 spin\u2013spin Bell pair).\n  2. A two\u2010node \u201crepeater\u201d teleportation: teleport spin A\u2192spin C via intermediate spin B on chip, using two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs and chained post\u2010selected Bell measurements, all in an integrated waveguide.\n  3. A \u201cquantum router\u201d that coherently teleports a spin\u2010qubit |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 into a superposition of arriving at spin\u2010qubit B or C, by splitting the Bell\u2010measurement arm into two on\u2010chip photonic branches\u2014no feed\u2010forward, purely post\u2010selected.\nStep 2: Assess novelty vs. past Pytheus targets:\n  1. Too close to standard swapping protocols.\n  2. Essentially a chain of two swaps\u2014interesting but expected.\n  3. The \u201crouter\u201d with coherent superposition of teleportation destinations is genuinely new and goes beyond fixed\u2010path teleportation or swapping, yet requires only pair sources, beam splitters, and heralding.\nStep 3: Choose idea (3) as most promising.\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus target realizes teleportation into a quantum superposition of different recipient nodes\u2014here the choice of final node B or C is itself coherent, not classically decided.\nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus since it uses only:\n  \u2022 Abstract Bell\u2010pair sources for A\u2013photon, B\u2013photon, C\u2013photon (coherent light\u2013matter interfaces).\n  \u2022 A static integrated waveguide network splitting the traveling photon into two Bell\u2010measurement blocks.\n  \u2022 Post\u2010selected ancilla detectors to herald teleportation success\u2014no dynamic feed\u2010forward.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014an integrated\u2010photonic \u201cquantum router\u201d that teleports a spin\u2010qubit |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 to nodes B or C in coherent superposition, heralded by post\u2010selected photonic detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label three stationary qubit nodes on chip: A (mode 0), B (mode 1), C (mode 2). Three coherent light\u2013matter interfaces produce three abstract Bell pairs:\n  \u2022 S\u2081: entangles qubit A (0) with photonic mode 3.  \n  \u2022 S\u2082: entangles qubit B (1) with photonic mode 4.  \n  \u2022 S\u2083: entangles qubit C (2) with photonic mode 5.  \n\nWe wish to teleport an unknown state |\u03c8\u27e9 from A into a coherent superposition of B and C. Photonic mode 3 is passed through an integrated 50:50 splitter that routes it equally into two Bell\u2010analyzer blocks:\n  \u2013 Block B: joint Bell measurement on modes (3\u2081,4) to teleport to B, heralded by clicks in ancilla detectors 6 & 7.\n  \u2013 Block C: joint Bell measurement on modes (3\u2082,5) to teleport to C, heralded by clicks in ancilla detectors 8 & 9.\n\nBecause the splitter acts coherently, a successful pair of clicks in {6,7} vs. {8,9} projects the final state to |\u03c8\u27e9 at B or at C\u2014but before detection the destination is in superposition. The overall abstract post\u2010selected mapping is:\n\n  |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080 \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{1,4} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{2,5}\n    \u2192 ( |\u03c8\u27e9\u2081 \u2297 |clicks\u27e9_{6,7} + |\u03c8\u27e9\u2082 \u2297 |clicks\u27e9_{8,9} ).\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21943)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21944)]   [S\u2083:(2\u21945)]  \ncircuit:    [split 3 \u2192 two Bell blocks on (3,4) and (3,5)]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][anc6][anc7][anc8][anc9]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"Quantum\u2010router: coherent superposition teleportation A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  foldername          : \"quantum_router_teleport\",\n  edges_tried         : 30,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 4,             # ancillas 6,7,8,9\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 12,\n  target_quantum      : [\"\u03c8@1+\u03c8@2\"],   # abstract superposition target on modes 1&2 conditioned on ancillas\n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [1,2],  \n  heralding_out       : null,\n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],  \n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [6,7,8,9],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N possible destinations by splitting into N Bell\u2010analyzers.  \n  \u2013 Forms a new primitive for coherent routing in integrated photonic quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the known dual\u2010destination teleportation switch without substantive innovation. On\u2010chip entanglement swapping of two spin qubits via a linear\u2010optics Bell\u2010analyzer (spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 spin\u2013spin Bell).\n    2. A two\u2010segment repeater chain: teleport spin A\u2192spin C via spin B on chip, using two chained post\u2010selected Bell measurements.\n    3. On\u2010chip entanglement purification of two noisy spin memories: generate two spin\u2013photon pairs, interfere their photons in an integrated circuit to perform a parity check, and post\u2010select to herald a purified spin\u2013spin Bell pair.\n  Step 2: Evaluate novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    1. Too close to earlier spin\u2013photon swap proposals.\n    2. Basically two sequential swaps\u2014interesting but expected.\n    3. Purification is genuinely new for Pytheus: it implements a network transformation beyond swap/teleport, uses only probabilistic pair sources and linear optics, no dynamic feedback, and can be generalized to multiple rounds.\n  Step 3: Choose idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty: No previous Pytheus target performs entanglement purification on coherent\u2010light\u2010matter qubit memories via an on\u2010chip parity\u2010check circuit. This extends network protocols into error\u2010mitigation.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can encode two abstract Bell\u2010pair sources (spin\u2013photon), a passive integrated beam\u2010splitter parity network on the two photons, and two ancilla detectors for post\u2010selection. No cavities or feed\u2010forward are needed.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014an integrated\u2010photonic entanglement\u2010purification primitive for two spin qubits, using coherent light\u2013matter interfaces and linear optics:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label two stationary spin\u2010qubit nodes on chip: Q\u2081 (mode 0) and Q\u2082 (mode 1). Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each generate a (noisy) abstract Bell pair:\n \u2022 S\u2081 produces entanglement between spin 0 and photon mode 2.  \n \u2022 S\u2082 produces entanglement between spin 1 and photon mode 3.  \n\nThese two raw spin\u2013photon Bell pairs suffer dephasing or imperfect fidelity. We wish to purify them into a single higher\u2010fidelity spin\u2013spin Bell pair on nodes 0&1. To do so, we interfere the two photons (modes 2,3) in an integrated parity\u2010check circuit: a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifter network that effectively implements a photonic parity measurement. Two number\u2010resolving detectors (modes 4 & 5) herald a successful even\u2010parity outcome. Conditioned on one click in each detector (post\u2010selection), the remaining spins collapse into a purified Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates on\u2010chip entanglement purification of matter qubit memories.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21942)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21943)]  \nparity\u2010circuit:  [BS(2,3) + phase network]  \ndetectors:   [spin-read@0][spin-read@1][anc@4][anc@5]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"On-chip entanglement purification of two spin qubits via photonic parity check\",\n  foldername          : \"spin_purification_chip\",\n  edges_tried         : 25,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 2,               # detectors 4 & 5\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 10,\n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],     # purified spin pair on nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [0,1],\n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [4,5],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2013 Cascaded purification: chain multiple rounds by feeding in additional raw pairs.  \n \u2013 Multipartite purification: extend to three or more spins via multi-photon parity checks.  \n \u2013 Forms a building block for on-chip error mitigation in scalable photonic\u2013matter quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to known entanglement purification protocols (including on-chip qutrit purification and passive Bell-filter networks) and offers no fundamentally new element. Chained teleportation A\u2192B\u2192C on chip: two sequential, post\u2010selected Bell measurements transferring a spin\u2010qubit along a repeater link.\n    3. Photonic quantum\u2010network coding in the butterfly topology: two senders teleport their qubits through a network with a single\u2010channel bottleneck by coherently mixing photons in an integrated circuit.\n  Step 2: Novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    1. Too close to existing swap proposals.\n    2. Expected chain of swaps.\n    3. Quantum network coding (QNC) is genuinely new to Pytheus: it\u2019s a nontrivial network protocol, uses only Bell\u2010pair sources, beam splitters, detectors, and fits Pytheus\u2019s static\u2010optics paradigm.\n  Step 3: Choose idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty: No prior Pytheus target implements a quantum\u2010butterfly network coding protocol for teleportation\u2014this introduces network\u2010coding primitives into integrated quantum\u2010optics experiments.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can place four coherent light\u2013matter Bell sources (two at senders, two at receivers), an integrated photonic butterfly circuit of beam splitters and phase shifters, and number\u2010resolving ancilla detectors to post\u2010select the network\u2010coded Bell measurements\u2014no feedback or cavities required.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014an integrated\u2010photonic \u201cbutterfly\u201d quantum\u2010network coding teleportation:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label four on\u2010chip spin nodes (qubits): S\u2081 (mode 0), S\u2082 (mode 1), R\u2081 (mode 2), R\u2082 (mode 3).  \nFour coherent light\u2013matter interfaces generate abstract Bell pairs:\n \u2022 S\u2081 entangles qubit 0 \u21d4 photon 4  \n \u2022 S\u2082 entangles qubit 1 \u21d4 photon 5  \n \u2022 R\u2081 entangles qubit 2 \u21d4 photon 6  \n \u2022 R\u2082 entangles qubit 3 \u21d4 photon 7  \n\nGoal: teleport unknown states |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080 and |\u03d5\u27e9\u2081 at senders S\u2081,S\u2082 to receivers R\u2081,R\u2082, respectively, over a network that has only one physical photonic \u201cbottleneck\u201d link. The integrated photonic circuit implements the butterfly network coding: it combines photons 4 & 5 on a 50:50 coupler, splits outputs into two arms, and then each arm interferes with photon 6 or 7 in a Bell\u2010measurement block. Two pairs of ancilla detectors (modes 8&9 for R\u2081\u2010branch, 10&11 for R\u2082\u2010branch) herald successful network\u2010coded teleportation events. Conditioned on one click in each ancilla pair, the final spins at R\u2081&R\u2082 hold |\u03c8\u27e9 and |\u03d5\u27e9, despite sharing only one shared waveguide for the two senders.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21944)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21945)]   [R\u2081:(2\u21946)]   [R\u2082:(3\u21947)]  \ncircuit:     [butterfly: 4+5 \u2192 coupler \u2192 two BS\u2013Bell blocks with 6,7]  \ndetectors:   [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][spin\u2010read@3][anc8][anc9][anc10][anc11]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"Integrated\u2010photonic butterfly quantum\u2010network coding teleportation\",\n  foldername          : \"butterfly_qnc_teleport\",\n  edges_tried         : 30,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 4,               # detectors 8,9,10,11\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 12,\n  target_quantum      : [\"\u03c8@2\",\"\u03d5@3\"],   # teleportation outputs on modes 2 & 3\n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [2,3],\n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [8,9,10,11],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nKey Points:\n  \u2013 Coherent light\u2013matter interfaces provide the four Bell\u2010pair sources.  \n  \u2013 The butterfly circuit is a static linear\u2010optics network of 50:50 beam splitters and phase shifters on chip.  \n  \u2013 Post\u2010selection on ancilla detectors implements the network\u2010coded Bell measurements that overcome the bottleneck.  \n  \u2013 No state\u2010generation: the target is the teleportation transformation across a nontrivial network.  \n  \u2013 Generalizes to other network\u2010coding topologies (e.g. 2\u21923 cross\u2010bar, N\u2010sender multicast).  \n\nThis new protocol marries coherent light\u2013matter entanglement sources with integrated photonic network coding, opening a path to on\u2010chip QNC primitives for future quantum internets.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the existing butterfly network coding teleportation (including the SiV spin-qubit version) without substantive innovation. A combined purification + swapping repeater segment: start with two noisy spin\u2013photon Bell\u2010pairs (A\u2013B and B\u2013C), first purify via a photonic parity check, then swap purified links to entangle A\u2013C\u2014all in one static integrated circuit.\n  Step 2: Assess novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    1. Too close to existing swap proposals.\n    2. Essentially two standard swaps in series.\n    3. The purification-swap repeater node is genuinely new for Pytheus: it fuses two network primitives (entanglement purification + swapping) into one passive circuit*, uses only pair sources, beam splitters, and heralding detectors, and no dynamic feedback.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty: No prior Pytheus target combines purification and entanglement swapping into a single static photonic circuit acting on matter\u2010qubit memories.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can encode four coherent light\u2013matter Bell-pair sources, a two-stage beam-splitter network (one parity\u2010check BS on the middle photonic modes, one Bell\u2010analyzer BS on the outer modes), and number-resolving detectors for post-selection.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014an on-chip \u201cpurification-swap repeater node\u201d that (i) purifies two imperfect spin\u2013photon Bell pairs at A\u2013B and B\u2013C, then (ii) swaps the purified entanglement to A\u2013C\u2014all implemented with coherent light\u2013matter interfaces and a static integrated photonic circuit:\n\nExplanation:\nWe have four stationary matter\u2010qubit nodes on chip:\n  \u2022 Q\u2081 (mode 0, \u201cA\u201d)  \n  \u2022 Q\u2082 (mode 1, first B qubit)  \n  \u2022 Q\u2083 (mode 2, second B qubit)  \n  \u2022 Q\u2084 (mode 3, \u201cC\u201d)\n\nFour coherent light\u2013matter Bell\u2010pair sources create two noisy Bell links:\n  \u2022 S\u2081 emits a (noisy) Bell pair between Q\u2081\u2194photon 4  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 emits a (noisy) Bell pair between Q\u2082\u2194photon 5  \n  \u2022 S\u2083 emits a (noisy) Bell pair between Q\u2083\u2194photon 6  \n  \u2022 S\u2084 emits a (noisy) Bell pair between Q\u2084\u2194photon 7  \n\nSequence of photonic operations (all on chip, no dynamic control):\n  1. Parity\u2010check (purification) on the middle two photons (5 & 6):  \n     \u2013 They interfere on a 50:50 beam splitter + phase shifter network.  \n     \u2013 Number\u2010resolving detectors  eight (ancilla 8) & nine (ancilla 9) herald an even-parity click pattern \u2192 projects the remaining two spin\u2013photon pairs into higher-fidelity Bell pairs at A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n  2. Entanglement swapping on the purified outer photons (4 & 7):  \n     \u2013 They enter a standard linear-optics Bell\u2010state analyzer (BS + phase network).  \n     \u2013 Number\u2010resolving detectors ten (ancilla 10) & eleven (ancilla 11) herald a successful Bell outcome \u2192 remotely entangles Q\u2081 (A) and Q\u2084 (C) into a purified Bell pair.\n\nPost\u2010selection on clicks in ancilla detectors {8,9} and {10,11} yields a single high-fidelity Bell state between A and C.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21944)] [S\u2082:(1\u21945)] [S\u2083:(2\u21946)] [S\u2084:(3\u21947)]  \ncircuit:    [BS(5,6)+phase \u2192 anc8,anc9]  \n            [BS(4,7)+phase \u2192 anc10,anc11]  \ndetectors:  [spin-read@0][spin-read@3][anc8][anc9][anc10][anc11]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"On-chip combined purification + swapping repeater node\",\n  foldername          : \"purify_swap_repeater\",\n  edges_tried         : 25,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 4,                # detectors 8,9,10,11\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 12,\n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],      # purified Bell on Q\u2081 & Q\u2084\n  in_nodes            : [],\n  out_nodes           : [0,3],\n  single_emitters     : [],\n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],               # allow full routing\n  anc_detectors       : [8,9,10,11],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nKey Points:\n  \u2013 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction: four on-chip Bell\u2010pair sources.  \n  \u2013 Integrated photonic circuit: two BS + phase-networks (parity check then Bell analyzer).  \n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward: purely post-selected heralding.  \n  \u2013 Network transformation: two noisy links \u2192 purified, swapped link\u2014repeater primitive.  \n  \u2013 Generalizes to cascaded rounds (multiple purification-swap segments) and multi-memory networks.\n\nThis primitive opens a new class of on-chip quantum-network nodes that jointly purify and extend entanglement in one passive photonic circuit, a capability not yet explored by Pytheus.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the known one-shot swap-and-concentrate repeater node without adding a fundamentally new element. To achieve genuine novelty, you need to propose a repeater primitive that cannot be reduced to sequential parity\u2010filter plus Bell\u2010swap\u2014e.g. an indefinite\u2010order purification-swap, multi-party catalytic purification, or a topology-protected repeater supermap that goes beyond simple post-selected concentration.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! On\u2010chip entanglement swapping of two spin qubits via a linear\u2010optics Bell analyzer (spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 spin\u2013spin Bell).\n  2. Chained teleportation A\u2192B\u2192C on chip: two sequential, post\u2010selected Bell measurements transferring a spin\u2010qubit along a repeater link.\n  3. A quantum\u2010switch for entanglement\u2010swapping: superpose two different orders of Bell\u2010measurements on a single integrated circuit, heralded by post\u2010selected detection.\nStep 2: Assessment:\n  1. No dynamic control is needed\u2014just static linear optics and heralded detection.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014an on\u2010chip quantum\u2010switch for entanglement\u2010swapping, combining coherent light\u2013matter Bell\u2010pair sources with an integrated photonic supermap:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label three on\u2010chip spin\u2010qubit nodes: Control (0), A (1), C (2). Three coherent light\u2013matter interfaces produce abstract Bell pairs:\n \u2022 S\u2080 entangles Control(0) \u2194 photon p\u2080  \n \u2022 S\u2081 entangles A(1) \u2194 photon p\u2081  \n \u2022 S\u2082 entangles C(2) \u2194 photon p\u2082  \n\nGoal: entangle A and C via two successive Bell\u2010measurements on the photons, but with the order of those two measurements placed in quantum superposition\u2014i.e., realize a \u201cquantum switch\u201d of two swapping channels.  \n\nIntegrated circuit:\n \u2022 Photonic modes p\u2081 and p\u2082 pass through a 50:50 integrated splitter network controlled by p\u2080 (the control photon).  \n \u2022 Depending on the path in the splitter, p\u2081 first meets p\u2082 in Bell\u2010analyzer Module \u03b1 then Module \u03b2, or vice versa; because p\u2080 is in a superposition, the ordering of \u03b1 and \u03b2 is coherently superposed.  \n \u2022 Each Bell\u2010module is a beam splitter + phase\u2010shifter block with two ancilla detectors: Module \u03b1 \u2192 detectors d\u2083,d\u2084; Module \u03b2 \u2192 detectors d\u2085,d\u2086.  \n\nPost\u2010selection:\n \u2022 A click in one detector pair of \u03b1 and one of \u03b2 heralds a successful \u201cswitch\u2010ed\u201d entanglement\u2010swap.\n \u2022 Conditioned on these four clicks, spins A and C collapse into a Bell pair whose creation process had no definite order. Control qubit 0 remains entangled with which order \u201chappened,\u201d realizing the quantum\u2010switch resource state.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:   [S\u2080:(0\u2194p\u2080)]  [S\u2081:(1\u2194p\u2081)]  [S\u2082:(2\u2194p\u2082)]  \ncircuit:    [p\u2081,p\u2082,p\u2080 \u2192 integrated MZI\u2013style split & two Bell\u2010modules \u03b1,\u03b2]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2013read@0][spin\u2013read@1][spin\u2013read@2][d\u2083][d\u2084][d\u2085][d\u2086]\n\nKey points:\n \u2022 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction enters via the three Bell\u2010pair sources.  \n \u2022 Integrated photonic circuit implements a passive quantum switch\u2014indefinite order of two Bell\u2010measurements.  \n \u2022 Purely post-selected, no dynamic feedback.  \n \u2022 The abstract target is not a static many-qubit state, but the higher-order transformation (\u201csupermap\u201d) that superposes two network channels.  \n \u2022 This primitive can be generalized to superpositions of N different network topologies (e.g. parallel vs. series links) and opens a new class of on-chip quantum\u2010network operations beyond fixed paths.  \n\nThis proposal merges coherent spin\u2013photon interfaces with on-chip indefinite\u2010order photonic routing, offering a first demonstration of a quantum switch in a quantum\u2010network context.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is effectively identical to the ensemble\u2019s entanglement-switch quantum switch proposal.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three distinct Pytheus\u2010compatible network\u2010operations merging coherent light\u2013matter interaction with an integrated photonic circuit (no simple state\u2010generation):\n    1. On\u2010chip entanglement purification plus swapping repeater node (two\u2010step parity filter + Bell swap).\n    2. Superposition\u2010of\u2010destination teleportation (\u201cquantum router\u201d).\n    3. Entanglement\u2010reconfiguration switch: dynamically reroute entanglement among four spin memories by cross\u2010swapping two Bell\u2010pairs in one static integrated circuit.\n  Step 2: Assess novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    1 & 2 have been criticized as too close to known protocols.  \n    3 is genuinely new for Pytheus: it realizes a reconfigurable entanglement\u2010switch primitive among four matter qubits by passive linear optics, using only pair sources, beam splitters, and heralding\u2014no feedback or cavities.\n  Step 3: Choose idea (3).\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because Pytheus has never targeted a multi\u2010pair entanglement\u2010reconfiguration switch that transforms one matching (0\u20131 & 2\u20133) into another (0\u20133 & 1\u20132) in a single passive circuit.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus: encode four coherent light\u2013matter Bell\u2010pair sources, two on\u2010chip Bell\u2010analyzers (BS + phase) acting on the four photons, and four ancilla detectors for post\u2010selection. The target is the abstract mapping from initial Bell links to cross\u2010swapped Bell links.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014an on\u2010chip entanglement\u2010reconfiguration switch for four spin\u2010qubit memories, using coherent light\u2013matter pair sources and a static integrated photonic circuit to cross\u2010swap two Bell pairs:\n\nExplanation:\nWe have four stationary spin qubits on an integrated photonic chip:\n  \u2022 Q\u2080 (mode 0)  \n  \u2022 Q\u2081 (mode 1)  \n  \u2022 Q\u2082 (mode 2)  \n  \u2022 Q\u2083 (mode 3)\n\nFour coherent light\u2013matter interfaces generate abstract Bell\u2010pairs:\n  \u2022 S\u2081 entangles Q\u2080\u2194photon 4  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 entangles Q\u2081\u2194photon 5  \n  \u2022 S\u2083 entangles Q\u2082\u2194photon 6  \n  \u2022 S\u2084 entangles Q\u2083\u2194photon 7\n\nInitially, post\u2010selecting Bell measurements on (4,5) and (6,7) would create entanglement links Q\u2080\u2013Q\u2081 and Q\u2082\u2013Q\u2083. We instead aim to reconfigure these links into Q\u2080\u2013Q\u2083 and Q\u2081\u2013Q\u2082 in one circuit. We route:\n  \u2013 Photons 4 & 7 into Bell\u2010analyzer \u03b1 (50:50 BS + phase network), with ancilla detectors 8 & 9.  \n  \u2013 Photons 5 & 6 into Bell\u2010analyzer \u03b2, with ancilla detectors 10 & 11.\n\nConditioned on one click in each detector pair {8,9} and {10,11} (post\u2010selection), the remaining spins collapse into the cross\u2010swapped Bell pairs:\n  \u2022 Q\u2080\u2013Q\u2083: (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)  \n  \u2022 Q\u2081\u2013Q\u2082: (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)\n\nThis implements an entanglement\u2010reconfiguration primitive\u2014an \u201con\u2010chip entanglement switch\u201d\u2014that transforms one pairing of memories into another via linear optics and heralded detection, without feedback control.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21944)] [S\u2082:(1\u21945)] [S\u2083:(2\u21946)] [S\u2084:(3\u21947)]  \ncircuit:     [BS & phase on (4,7) \u2192 anc8,9]  \n             [BS & phase on (5,6) \u2192 anc10,11]  \ndetectors:   [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][spin\u2010read@3][anc8][anc9][anc10][anc11]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"On\u2010chip entanglement\u2010reconfiguration switch for four spin memories\",\n  foldername          : \"ent_reconfig_cross_swap\",\n  edges_tried         : 30,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 4,\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 12,\n  target_quantum      : [\"0000\",\"0110\",\"1001\",\"1111\"],  #     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. By routing ancilla photons through a static 4\u00d74 multipath interferometer to erase which-swap information and postselecting on four-click coincidences, we realize in one shot the coherent entanglement routing across all pairing geometries.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Four-Party GHZ Entanglement-Swapping Star with 3\u21921 Network Steering\n\nAbstract: We implement a single-step four-photon GHZ entanglement-swapping star that fuses four independent probabilistic Bell-pair sources at a central station via a linear-optical 4-photon GHZ projector to realize the target 4-party GHZ resource. Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \n\u201cCyclic-Graph Teleportation with Passive Pauli Cancellation and Measurement-Controlled Phase Gate\u201d\n\nAbstract  \nWe implement a static linear-optical protocol that teleports an unknown qubit from Alice (mode 0) to Bob (mode 3) by entangling four probabilistic Bell pairs into a cycle graph, passively canceling all Pauli by-products and embedding a measurement-controlled Z-rotation on the teleported state without any active feed-forward. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a fully specified target for Pytheus\u2014an on-chip, post-selected entanglement swap between two matter qubits mediated by an integrated photonic Bell-state analyzer.\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider two stationary spin qubits (e.g. quantum-dot exciton levels) on an integrated photonic chip, labelled nodes 0 and 1. Each spin is initially entangled with an emitted photon via a coherent light\u2013matter interaction on chip, realizing two independent Bell pairs:\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2081 emits an abstract Bell state between spin-mode 0 and photonic mode 2.\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2082 emits an identical Bell state between spin-mode 1 and photonic mode 3.\nThe two photons (modes 2 & 3) are routed by an integrated waveguide circuit into a linear-optics Bell-state measurement (BSM) block (a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifters). Successful BSM outcomes are heralded by two ancillary detectors (modes 4 & 5). Conditioned on a click in each ancilla detector (post-selection), the two remote spins (nodes 0 & 1) collapse into a maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates photonic-mediated entanglement swapping of matter qubits on chip.\n\nVisualization (modes going top\u2192bottom):\nemitters: [ S\u2081: (0\u21942) ]  [ S\u2082: (1\u21943) ]  \ncircuit: [ waveguide routing 2 & 3 into 50:50 BS + phase shifter network ]  \ndetectors: [spin-readout@0][spin-readout@1][detector@2][detector@3][ancilla@4][ancilla@5]\n\nKey points:\n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward: success is post-selected by ancilla clicks.\n  \u2013 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction enters via the two initial Bell-pair sources.\n  \u2013 Entire Bell-measurement circuit and routing is realized in an integrated photonic waveguide architecture.\n  \u2013 The target is the abstract transformation: two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 post-selected spin\u2013spin Bell pair (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9).\n  \u2013 This protocol can be generalized to multiple nodes (linear repeater chains or networks with star/topologies).\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description: \"On-chip entanglement swapping between two spin qubits via photonic Bell-measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hybrid_spin_swap\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],        # Such spin\u2013photon mediated entanglement swapping has already been demonstrated in NV centers, quantum dots, and other platforms (e.g. Moehring et al. Nature 2007; Bernien et al. Nature 2013), and integrated photonic Bell analyzers are well\u2010explored. There is no new foundational feature, multi-node network effect, or higher-dimensional twist that would elevate this to PRL novelty.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too close to existing spin\u2013photon entanglement-swapping experiments and on-chip Bell analyzers. To be novel at the PRL level, you would need to introduce a genuinely new element\u2014e.g. an indefinite\u2010order swap, a heralded multi-qubit fusion primitive that cannot be reduced to standard swapping, or integration of nonclassical ancilla conservation that goes beyond straightforward photonic routing.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target configuration\u2014an integrated \u201cquantum\u2010router\u201d that teleports a spin\u2010qubit from node A to B or C in coherent superposition, heralded by post-selected photonic detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label three stationary spin qubits on chip: A (mode 0), B (mode 1), C (mode 2). Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each produce an abstract Bell pair:\n  \u2022 S\u2081: entangles spin A (0) with photonic mode 3.  \n  \u2022 S\u2082: entangles spin B (1) with photonic mode 4.  \n  \u2022 S\u2083: entangles spin C (2) with photonic mode 5.  \n\nWe wish to teleport an arbitrary input state |\u03c8\u27e9 on spin A to either B or C, but in a controlled superposition. We build an integrated photonic circuit that routes mode 3 equally into two Bell\u2010measurement blocks:\n  \u2013 Block 1 jointly measures modes (3 & 4) to teleport to B.\n  \u2013 Block 2 jointly measures modes (3 & 5) to teleport to C.\n\nA 50:50 directional coupler splits mode 3 into paths to both blocks; the two Bell\u2010analyzers are realized with beam splitters and phase shifters on chip. Each block has two ancilla detectors (modes 6,7 for B-branch and modes 8,9 for C-branch). A pair of clicks in either the B-branch detectors or the C-branch detectors heralds successful teleportation to B or C, respectively\u2014but because the split was coherent, the teleportation destination remains in superposition until detection. The final abstract mapping is:\n\n  |\u03c8\u27e9_A \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{B4} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{C5}\n    \u2192 ( |\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{6,7} + |\u03c8\u27e9_C\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{8,9} )\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21943)]  [S\u2082:(1\u21944)]  [S\u2083:(2\u21945)]  \ncircuit:    [split 3 \u2192 path to Bell-analyzer(3,4) + Bell-analyzer(3,5)]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][anc6][anc7][anc8][anc9]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description       : \"On\u2010chip superposition\u2010of\u2010destinations quantum router via post\u2010selected teleportation\",\n  foldername        : \"quantum_router_teleport\",\n  edges_tried       : 30,\n  ftol              : 1e-06,\n  loss_func         : \"cr\",\n  num_anc           : 4,            # detectors 6,7,8,9\n  optimizer         : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples           : 12,\n  target_quantum    : [\"0B\",\"1B\",\"0C\",\"1C\"], # abstract mapping onto spin B or C\n  in_nodes          : [],\n  out_nodes         : [1,2,6,7,8,9], \n  single_emitters   : [],\n  amplitudes        : [],\n  removed_connections: [],          # allow all beam\u2010splitter couplings\n  anc_detectors     : [6,7,8,9],\n  number_resolving  : true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Can be extended to N output nodes by splitting into N Bell blocks.  \n  \u2013 Forms a building block for photonic\u2010mediated quantum networks on a chip: coherent routing primitives beyond fixed\u2010path swapping.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a spin\u2010qubit version of the \u201cdual\u2010destination teleportation switch\u201d already in the ensemble list (see \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\u201d). Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each generate a (noisy) abstract Bell pair:\n \u2022 S\u2081 produces entanglement between spin 0 and photon mode 2.  \n \u2022 S\u2082 produces entanglement between spin 1 and photon mode 3.  \n\nThese two raw spin\u2013photon Bell pairs suffer dephasing or imperfect fidelity. Two number\u2010resolving detectors (modes 4 & 5) herald a successful even\u2010parity outcome.     "output": "Thought: This proposal simply implements two independent entanglement swaps (4\u21947 and 5\u21946) to cross\u2010link four spin memories (Q\u2080\u2013Q\u2083 and Q\u2081\u2013Q\u2082).  That is just standard entanglement swapping applied twice in parallel\u2014no new measurement primitive, no superposition of matchings, no nontrivial causal order, and no higher-dimensional or topologically protected feature.  Such cross-swapping with two Bell projections is trivial and already well explored.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This scheme reduces to two parallel entanglement\u2010swapping steps\u2014a known and elementary operation. To reach PRL novelty you need a genuine new network primitive (e.g. coherent superposition of multiple matchings, indefinite\u2010order swapping, multi-party fusion beyond pairwise swaps, or a non-trivial topological effect) rather than back-to-back Bell measurements."

{
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. Each spin is initially entangled with an emitted photon via a coherent light\u2013matter interaction on chip, realizing two independent Bell pairs:\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2081 emits an abstract Bell state between spin-mode 0 and photonic mode 2.\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2082 emits an identical Bell state between spin-mode 1 and photonic mode 3.\nThe two photons (modes 2 & 3) are routed by an integrated waveguide circuit into a linear-optics Bell-state measurement (BSM) block (a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifters). Successful BSM outcomes are heralded by two ancillary detectors (modes 4 & 5). Conditioned on a click in each ancilla detector (post-selection), the two remote spins (nodes 0 & 1) collapse into a maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates photonic-mediated entanglement swapping of matter qubits on chip.\n\nVisualization (modes going top\u2192bottom):\nemitters: [ S\u2081: (0\u21942) ]  [ S\u2082: (1\u21943) ]  \ncircuit: [ waveguide routing 2 & 3 into 50:50 BS + phase shifter network ]  \ndetectors: [spin-readout@0][spin-readout@1][detector@2][detector@3][ancilla@4][ancilla@5]\n\nKey points:\n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward: success is post-selected by ancilla clicks.\n  \u2013 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction enters via the two initial Bell-pair sources.\n  \u2013 Entire Bell-measurement circuit and routing is realized in an integrated photonic waveguide architecture.\n  \u2013 The target is the abstract transformation: two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 post-selected spin\u2013spin Bell pair (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9).\n  \u2013 This protocol can be generalized to multiple nodes (linear repeater chains or networks with star/topologies).\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description: \"On-chip entanglement swapping between two spin qubits via photonic Bell-measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hybrid_spin_swap\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],        # spin nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes: [],                       # pair sources define inputs\n  out_nodes: [0,1],\n  heralding_out: null,\n  single_emitters: [],                # abstract pair sources instead\n  amplitudes: [],\n  removed_connections: [],            # allow all routing\n  anc_detectors: [4,5],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to existing spin\u2013photon entanglement-swapping experiments and on-chip Bell analyzers. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible hybrid network ideas combining coherent light\u2013matter interaction with an integrated photonic circuit, focusing on entanglement swapping or teleportation rather than raw state generation:\n    1. On\u2010chip entanglement swapping of two quantum\u2010dot spins via an integrated linear\u2010optics Bell\u2010analyzer (spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 spin\u2013spin Bell).\n    2. A two\u2010node repeater teleportation segment: teleport a spin\u2010qubit\u2019s state from node A to node C via an intermediate spin memory B, all on chip, using two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs and chained post-selected Bell measurements.\n    3. A \u201cquantum router\u201d that teleports a spin\u2010qubit\u2019s state from A to either B or C, but in a coherent superposition of destinations, by using an on\u2010chip photonic network that splits the Bell\u2010measurement in two branches and recombines them\u2014no feedback, purely post-selected.\n  Step 2: Assess novelty and Pytheus feasibility:\n    1. Too close to existing hybrid swap protocols (and prior photonic Bell analyzers).\n    2. Essentially a chained swap; interesting but conceptually expected.\n    3. Superposition\u2010of\u2010teleportation\u2010routes \u201cquantum router\u201d is genuinely new: it is not mere state generation but a novel network transformation, requires no dynamic control, uses only pair sources, beamsplitters, and heralding.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no prior Pytheus target implements teleportation with coherent superposition of the teleportation destination\u2014it elevates a static swap network into a true quantum\u2010routing primitive.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus since we can encode:\n    \u2022 Two spin\u2013photon Bell\u2010pair sources on chip (coherent light\u2013matter interfaces).  \n    \u2022 A static linear\u2010optics circuit that splits the \u201cBell\u2010measurement\u201d arm into two identical analyzers (one coupling to node B\u2019s ancilla photon, one to C\u2019s).  \n    \u2022 Post\u2010selected ancilla detectors heralding a successful teleportation, with no feed\u2010forward needed.  \n    \u2022 Abstract qubit encoding so Pytheus finds beam splitter phases and coupling to realize the target mapping.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target configuration\u2014an integrated \u201cquantum\u2010router\u201d that teleports a spin\u2010qubit from node A to B or C in coherent superposition, heralded by post-selected photonic detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label three stationary spin qubits on chip: A (mode 0), B (mode 1), C (mode 2). Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each produce an abstract Bell pair:\n  \u2022 S\u2081: entangles spin A (0) with photonic mode 3.  \n  \u2022 S\u2082: entangles spin B (1) with photonic mode 4.  \n  \u2022 S\u2083: entangles spin C (2) with photonic mode 5.  \n\nWe wish to teleport an arbitrary input state |\u03c8\u27e9 on spin A to either B or C, but in a controlled superposition. We build an integrated photonic circuit that routes mode 3 equally into two Bell\u2010measurement blocks:\n  \u2013 Block 1 jointly measures modes (3 & 4) to teleport to B.\n  \u2013 Block 2 jointly measures modes (3 & 5) to teleport to C.\n\nA 50:50 directional coupler splits mode 3 into paths to both blocks; the two Bell\u2010analyzers are realized with beam splitters and phase shifters on chip. Each block has two ancilla detectors (modes 6,7 for B-branch and modes 8,9 for C-branch). A pair of clicks in either the B-branch detectors or the C-branch detectors heralds successful teleportation to B or C, respectively\u2014but because the split was coherent, the teleportation destination remains in superposition until detection. The final abstract mapping is:\n\n  |\u03c8\u27e9_A \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{B4} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{C5}\n    \u2192 ( |\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{6,7} + |\u03c8\u27e9_C\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{8,9} )\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21943)]  [S\u2082:(1\u21944)]  [S\u2083:(2\u21945)]  \ncircuit:    [split 3 \u2192 path to Bell-analyzer(3,4) + Bell-analyzer(3,5)]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][anc6][anc7][anc8][anc9]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description       : \"On\u2010chip superposition\u2010of\u2010destinations quantum router via post\u2010selected teleportation\",\n  foldername        : \"quantum_router_teleport\",\n  edges_tried       : 30,\n  ftol              : 1e-06,\n  loss_func         : \"cr\",\n  num_anc           : 4,            # detectors 6,7,8,9\n  optimizer         : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples           : 12,\n  target_quantum    : [\"0B\",\"1B\",\"0C\",\"1C\"], # abstract mapping onto spin B or C\n  in_nodes          : [],\n  out_nodes         : [1,2,6,7,8,9], \n  single_emitters   : [],\n  amplitudes        : [],\n  removed_connections: [],          # allow all beam\u2010splitter couplings\n  anc_detectors     : [6,7,8,9],\n  number_resolving  : true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Can be extended to N output nodes by splitting into N Bell blocks.  \n  \u2013 Forms a building block for photonic\u2010mediated quantum networks on a chip: coherent routing primitives beyond fixed\u2010path swapping.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s dual\u2010destination teleportation switch in matter\u2010photonic form without adding a genuinely new element. We wish to purify them into a single higher\u2010fidelity spin\u2013spin Bell pair on nodes 0&1. To do so, we interfere the two photons (modes 2,3) in an integrated parity\u2010check circuit: a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifter network that effectively implements a photonic parity measurement. Two number\u2010resolving detectors (modes 4 & 5) herald a successful even\u2010parity outcome. Conditioned on one click in each detector (post\u2010selection), the remaining spins collapse into a purified Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates on\u2010chip entanglement purification of matter qubit memories.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21942)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21943)]  \nparity\u2010circuit:  [BS(2,3) + phase network]  \ndetectors:   [spin-read@0][spin-read@1][anc@4][anc@5]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"On-chip entanglement purification of two spin qubits via photonic parity check\",\n  foldername          : \"spin_purification_chip\",\n  edges_tried         : 25,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 2,               # detectors 4 & 5\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 10,\n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],     # purified spin pair on nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [0,1],\n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [4,5],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2013 Cascaded purification: chain multiple rounds by feeding in additional raw pairs.  \n \u2013 Multipartite purification: extend to three or more spins via multi-photon parity checks.  \n \u2013 Forms a building block for on-chip error mitigation in scalable photonic\u2013matter quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to known entanglement purification protocols (including on-chip qutrit purification and passive Bell-filter networks) and offers no fundamentally new element. Two pairs of ancilla detectors (modes 8&9 for R\u2081\u2010branch, 10&11 for R\u2082\u2010branch) herald successful network\u2010coded teleportation events.  \n\nExplanation  \n---------  \nWe label two stationary spin-qubit memories on chip:  \n \u2022 Control qubit C at node 0  \n \u2022 Target  qubit T at node 1  \n\nStep\u20091: Coherent light\u2013matter Bell-pair sources  \n\u2014 On chip, two identical Bell-pair sources create abstract Bell states:  \n  S\u2081: entangles C(0) \u2194 photon p\u2082  \n  S\u2082: entangles T(1) \u2194 photon p\u2083  \n\nAfter these emissions the joint state is  \n  |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{0,2} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{1,3}  \nwhere |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080\u2081 = arbitrary input on C&T.\n\nStep\u20092: Gate-teleportation circuit  \n\u2014 Photons p\u2082 & p\u2083 are routed through an integrated photonic network that implements a **gate-teleportation CNOT**:  \n   \u2022 A 50\u223650 beam splitter + phase-shift network realizes a joint measurement in the basis  \n       {(|00\u27e9\u00b1|11\u27e9), (|01\u27e9\u00b1|10\u27e9)} on (p\u2082,p\u2083).  \n   \u2022 Two number-resolving detectors (ancilla modes a\u2084 & a\u2085) herald a specific \u201csuccessful\u201d outcome (one click in each).\n\nConditioned on clicks in {a\u2084,a\u2085}, the remaining spins at nodes 0 & 1 have undergone a CNOT:  \n\n   CNOT\u2080\u2192\u2081\u2009:\u2009|c,t\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u2192 |c,\u2009t\u2295c\u27e9\u2080\u2081  \n\nEverything is static and post-selected\u2014no dynamic feed-forward is required.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom)  \n emitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21942)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21943)]  \n circuit:    [50\u223650 BS + phase network on (2,3)]  \n detectors:  [spin-read@0][spin-read@1][ancilla@4][ancilla@5]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config  \n{  \n  description         : \"Heralded non-local CNOT between two spin qubits via on-chip gate teleporation\",  \n  foldername          : \"nonlocal_CNOT\",  \n  edges_tried         : 25,  \n  ftol                : 1e-6,  \n  loss_func           : \"gate_fidelity\",  \n  num_anc             : 2,                # detectors a4, a5  \n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  samples             : 12,  \n  target_process      : \"CNOT\",           # abstract two-qubit unitary  \n S2  \n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],  \n  removed_connections : [],               # allow full routing  \n  anc_detectors       : [4,5],  \n  number_resolving    : true  \n}  \n\nWhy it\u2019s novel  \n--------------  \n\u2013 Pytheus has seen heralded photonic CNOT gates and spin\u2013photon Bell swaps, but never a **remote, matter-qubit CNOT** effected entirely by on-chip coherent light\u2013matter sources plus linear optics.  \n\u2013 It elevates teleportation-based gate-teleportation into the domain of integrated photonic quantum networks, bridging coherent emitters with passive circuitry.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible  \n-----------------  \n\u2013 Uses only abstract Bell-pair sources (coherent light\u2013matter interfaces) plus 50\u223650 beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors, all within Pytheus\u2019s toolkit.  \n\u2013 Fully post-selected: no cavities or dynamic feedback.  \n\u2013 Directly generalizes to other two-qubit gates (CZ, SWAP) or multi-node gate chains for distributed quantum logic."
}

Successful BSM outcomes are heralded by two ancillary detectors (modes 4 & 5). Conditioned on a click in each ancilla detector (post-selection), the two remote spins (nodes 0 & 1) collapse into a maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates photonic-mediated entanglement swapping of matter qubits on chip.\n\nVisualization (modes going top\u2192bottom):\nemitters: [ S\u2081: (0\u21942) ]  [ S\u2082: (1\u21943) ]  \ncircuit: [ waveguide routing 2 & 3 into 50:50 BS + phase shifter network ]  \ndetectors: [spin-readout@0][spin-readout@1][detector@2][detector@3][ancilla@4][ancilla@5]\n\nKey points:\n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward: success is post-selected by ancilla clicks.\n  \u2013 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction enters via the two initial Bell-pair sources.\n  \u2013 Entire Bell-measurement circuit and routing is realized in an integrated photonic waveguide architecture.\n  \u2013 The target is the abstract transformation: two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 post-selected spin\u2013spin Bell pair (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9).\n  \u2013 This protocol can be generalized to multiple nodes (linear repeater chains or networks with star/topologies).\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description: \"On-chip entanglement swapping between two spin qubits via photonic Bell-measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hybrid_spin_swap\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],        # spin nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes: [],                       # pair sources define inputs\n  out_nodes: [0,1],\n  heralding_out: null,\n  single_emitters: [],                # abstract pair sources instead\n  amplitudes: [],\n  removed_connections: [],            # allow all routing\n  anc_detectors: [4,5],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to existing spin\u2013photon entanglement-swapping experiments and on-chip Bell analyzers.
