A \u201cquantum router\u201d that teleports a spin\u2010qubit\u2019s state from A to either B or C, but in a coherent superposition of destinations, by using an on\u2010chip photonic network that splits the Bell\u2010measurement in two branches and recombines them\u2014no feedback, purely post-selected.\n  Step 2: Assess novelty and Pytheus feasibility:\n    1. Too close to existing hybrid swap protocols (and prior photonic Bell analyzers).\n    2. Essentially a chained swap; interesting but conceptually expected.\n    3. Superposition\u2010of\u2010teleportation\u2010routes \u201cquantum router\u201d is genuinely new: it is not mere state generation but a novel network transformation, requires no dynamic control, uses only pair sources, beamsplitters, and heralding.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no prior Pytheus target implements teleportation with coherent superposition of the teleportation destination\u2014it elevates a static swap network into a true quantum\u2010routing primitive.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus since we can encode:\n    \u2022 Two spin\u2013photon Bell\u2010pair sources on chip (coherent light\u2013matter interfaces).  \n    \u2022 A static linear\u2010optics circuit that splits the \u201cBell\u2010measurement\u201d arm into two identical analyzers (one coupling to node B\u2019s ancilla photon, one to C\u2019s).  \n    \u2022 Post\u2010selected ancilla detectors heralding a successful teleportation, with no feed\u2010forward needed.  \n    \u2022 Abstract qubit encoding so Pytheus finds beam splitter phases and coupling to realize the target mapping.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target configuration\u2014an integrated \u201cquantum\u2010router\u201d that teleports a spin\u2010qubit from node A to B or C in coherent superposition, heralded by post-selected photonic detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label three stationary spin qubits on chip: A (mode 0), B (mode 1), C (mode 2). Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each produce an abstract Bell pair:\n  \u2022 S\u2081: entangles spin A (0) with photonic mode 3.  \n  \u2022 S\u2082: entangles spin B (1) with photonic mode 4.  \n  \u2022 S\u2083: entangles spin C (2) with photonic mode 5.  \n\nWe wish to teleport an arbitrary input state |\u03c8\u27e9 on spin A to either B or C, but in a controlled superposition. We build an integrated photonic circuit that routes mode 3 equally into two Bell\u2010measurement blocks:\n  \u2013 Block 1 jointly measures modes (3 & 4) to teleport to B.\n  \u2013 Block 2 jointly measures modes (3 & 5) to teleport to C.\n\nA 50:50 directional coupler splits mode 3 into paths to both blocks; the two Bell\u2010analyzers are realized with beam splitters and phase shifters on chip. Each block has two ancilla detectors (modes 6,7 for B-branch and modes 8,9 for C-branch). A pair of clicks in either the B-branch detectors or the C-branch detectors heralds successful teleportation to B or C, respectively\u2014but because the split was coherent, the teleportation destination remains in superposition until detection. The final abstract mapping is:\n\n  |\u03c8\u27e9_A \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{B4} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{C5}\n    \u2192 ( |\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{6,7} + |\u03c8\u27e9_C\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{8,9} )\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21943)]  [S\u2082:(1\u21944)]  [S\u2083:(2\u21945)]  \ncircuit:    [split 3 \u2192 path to Bell-analyzer(3,4) + Bell-analyzer(3,5)]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][anc6][anc7][anc8][anc9]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description       : \"On\u2010chip superposition\u2010of\u2010destinations quantum router via post\u2010selected teleportation\",\n  foldername        : \"quantum_router_teleport\",\n  edges_tried       : 30,\n  ftol              : 1e-06,\n  loss_func         : \"cr\",\n  num_anc           : 4,            # detectors 6,7,8,9\n  optimizer         : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples           : 12,\n  target_quantum    : [\"0B\",\"1B\",\"0C\",\"1C\"], # abstract mapping onto spin B or C\n  in_nodes          : [],\n  out_nodes         : [1,2,6,7,8,9], \n  single_emitters   : [],\n  amplitudes        : [],\n  removed_connections: [],          # allow all beam\u2010splitter couplings\n  anc_detectors     : [6,7,8,9],\n  number_resolving  : true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Can be extended to N output nodes by splitting into N Bell blocks.  \n  \u2013 Forms a building block for photonic\u2010mediated quantum networks on a chip: coherent routing primitives beyond fixed\u2010path swapping.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s dual\u2010destination teleportation switch in matter\u2010photonic form without adding a genuinely new element. To be novel enough for PRL, introduce a fundamentally different routing primitive (e.g. indefinite causal order, multi\u2010target fusion, or a new nonlocal supermap) rather than straightforward coherent path\u2010splitting and Bell measurements.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! On\u2010chip entanglement swapping of two spin qubits via a linear\u2010optics Bell\u2010analyzer (spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 spin\u2013spin Bell).\n    2. A two\u2010segment repeater chain: teleport spin A\u2192spin C via spin B on chip, using two chained post\u2010selected Bell measurements.\n    3. On\u2010chip entanglement purification of two noisy spin memories: generate two spin\u2013photon pairs, interfere their photons in an integrated circuit to perform a parity check, and post\u2010select to herald a purified spin\u2013spin Bell pair.\n  Step 2: Evaluate novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    1. Too close to earlier spin\u2013photon swap proposals.\n    2. Basically two sequential swaps\u2014interesting but expected.\n    3. Purification is genuinely new for Pytheus: it implements a network transformation beyond swap/teleport, uses only probabilistic pair sources and linear optics, no dynamic feedback, and can be generalized to multiple rounds.\n  Step 3: Choose idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty: No previous Pytheus target performs entanglement purification on coherent\u2010light\u2010matter qubit memories via an on\u2010chip parity\u2010check circuit. This extends network protocols into error\u2010mitigation.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can encode two abstract Bell\u2010pair sources (spin\u2013photon), a passive integrated beam\u2010splitter parity network on the two photons, and two ancilla detectors for post\u2010selection. No cavities or feed\u2010forward are needed.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014an integrated\u2010photonic entanglement\u2010purification primitive for two spin qubits, using coherent light\u2013matter interfaces and linear optics:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label two stationary spin\u2010qubit nodes on chip: Q\u2081 (mode 0) and Q\u2082 (mode 1). Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each generate a (noisy) abstract Bell pair:\n \u2022 S\u2081 produces entanglement between spin 0 and photon mode 2.  \n \u2022 S\u2082 produces entanglement between spin 1 and photon mode 3.  \n\nThese two raw spin\u2013photon Bell pairs suffer dephasing or imperfect fidelity. We wish to purify them into a single higher\u2010fidelity spin\u2013spin Bell pair on nodes 0&1. To do so, we interfere the two photons (modes 2,3) in an integrated parity\u2010check circuit: a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifter network that effectively implements a photonic parity measurement. Two number\u2010resolving detectors (modes 4 & 5) herald a successful even\u2010parity outcome. Conditioned on one click in each detector (post\u2010selection), the remaining spins collapse into a purified Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates on\u2010chip entanglement purification of matter qubit memories.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21942)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21943)]  \nparity\u2010circuit:  [BS(2,3) + phase network]  \ndetectors:   [spin-read@0][spin-read@1][anc@4][anc@5]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"On-chip entanglement purification of two spin qubits via photonic parity check\",\n  foldername          : \"spin_purification_chip\",\n  edges_tried         : 25,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 2,               # detectors 4 & 5\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 10,\n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],     # purified spin pair on nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [0,1],\n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [4,5],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2013 Cascaded purification: chain multiple rounds by feeding in additional raw pairs.  \n \u2013 Multipartite purification: extend to three or more spins via multi-photon parity checks.  \n \u2013 Forms a building block for on-chip error mitigation in scalable photonic\u2013matter quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to known entanglement purification protocols (including on-chip qutrit purification and passive Bell-filter networks) and offers no fundamentally new element. Quantum network coding (QNC) is genuinely new to Pytheus: it\u2019s a nontrivial network protocol, uses only Bell\u2010pair sources, beam splitters, detectors, and fits Pytheus\u2019s static\u2010optics paradigm.\n  Step 3: Choose idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty: No prior Pytheus target implements a quantum\u2010butterfly network coding protocol for teleportation\u2014this introduces network\u2010coding primitives into integrated quantum\u2010optics experiments.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can place four coherent light\u2013matter Bell sources (two at senders, two at receivers), an integrated photonic butterfly circuit of beam splitters and phase shifters, and number\u2010resolving ancilla detectors to post\u2010select the network\u2010coded Bell measurements\u2014no feedback or cavities required.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014an integrated\u2010photonic \u201cbutterfly\u201d quantum\u2010network coding teleportation:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label four on\u2010chip spin nodes (qubits): S\u2081 (mode 0), S\u2082 (mode 1), R\u2081 (mode 2), R\u2082 (mode 3).  \nFour coherent light\u2013matter interfaces generate abstract Bell pairs:\n \u2022 S\u2081 entangles qubit 0 \u21d4 photon 4  \n \u2022 S\u2082 entangles qubit 1 \u21d4 photon 5  \n \u2022 R\u2081 entangles qubit 2 \u21d4 photon 6  \n \u2022 R\u2082 entangles qubit 3 \u21d4 photon 7  \n\nGoal: teleport unknown states |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080 and |\u03d5\u27e9\u2081 at senders S\u2081,S\u2082 to receivers R\u2081,R\u2082, respectively, over a network that has only one physical photonic \u201cbottleneck\u201d link. The integrated photonic circuit implements the butterfly network coding: it combines photons 4 & 5 on a 50:50 coupler, splits outputs into two arms, and then each arm interferes with photon 6 or 7 in a Bell\u2010measurement block. Two pairs of ancilla detectors (modes 8&9 for R\u2081\u2010branch, 10&11 for R\u2082\u2010branch) herald successful network\u2010coded teleportation events. Conditioned on one click in each ancilla pair, the final spins at R\u2081&R\u2082 hold |\u03c8\u27e9 and |\u03d5\u27e9, despite sharing only one shared waveguide for the two senders.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21944)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21945)]   [R\u2081:(2\u21946)]   [R\u2082:(3\u21947)]  \ncircuit:     [butterfly: 4+5 \u2192 coupler \u2192 two BS\u2013Bell blocks with 6,7]  \ndetectors:   [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][spin\u2010read@3][anc8][anc9][anc10][anc11]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"Integrated\u2010photonic butterfly quantum\u2010network coding teleportation\",\n  foldername          : \"butterfly_qnc_teleport\",\n  edges_tried         : 30,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 4,               # On\u2010chip entanglement purification + swapping repeater node (parity check + Bell swap).\n    2. Coherent superposition of two teleportation protocols (\u201cquantum router\u201d).\n    3. Indefinite\u2010order entanglement\u2010swapping switch: superpose two different sequences of three spin\u2013spin swapping channels in one passive photonic circuit.\n  Step 2: Check novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    1 & 2 have been criticized as too close to known protocols.\n    3 is genuinely new for Pytheus: it implements a higher\u2010order supermap\u2014indefinite causal order of three entanglement\u2010swapping operations\u2014using only Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, and post-selected detectors.\n  Step 3: Choose idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty: No previous Pytheus experiment has realized an indefinite\u2010order superposition of three network\u2010channels (three Bell\u2010swapping steps) on chip. This goes beyond two\u2010channel quantum switches.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can encode four coherent spin\u2013photon Bell\u2010pair sources and a static multiport interferometer that routes the four photons through three Bell analyzers in either order (A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192D or D\u2192C\u2192B\u2192A) in superposition, post-selecting successful herald clicks. No cavities or dynamic feedback required.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014an on\u2010chip indefinite\u2010order entanglement\u2010swapping switch for four spin memories, realized with coherent light\u2013matter Bell\u2010pair sources and a passive integrated photonic circuit:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label four stationary spin\u2010qubit nodes on chip:\n  \u2022 Q_A (mode 0)\n  \u2022 Q_B (mode 1)\n  \u2022 Q_C (mode 2)\n  \u2022 Q_D (mode 3)\n\nFour coherent light\u2013matter interfaces produce four abstract Bell pairs:\n  S\u2081: Q_A \u2194 photon p\u2081  \n  S\u2082: Q_B \u2194 photon p\u2082  \n  S\u2083: Q_C \u2194 photon p\u2083  \n  S\u2084: Q_D \u2194 photon p\u2084  \n\nGoal: entangle Q_A and Q_D by performing three Bell\u2010swap operations in a superposition of two different sequences:\n  \u2013 Path \u201cforward\u201d: M_{AB}(p\u2081,p\u2082) \u2192 M_{BC}(p\u2082,p\u2083) \u2192 M_{CD}(p\u2083,p\u2084)  \n  \u2013 Path \u201cbackward\u201d: M_{CD}(p\u2083,p\u2084) \u2192 M_{BC}(p\u2082,p\u2083) \u2192 M_{AB}(p\u2081,p\u2082)\n\nBecause the three \u201cswap modules\u201d share the photons p\u2081\u2013p\u2084, we route them through a 4\u00d74 symmetric multiport interferometer that creates a coherent superposition of the two ordering paths. Each swap module M is a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase network with two ancilla detectors:\n  \u2013 M_{AB}: detectors d\u2085,d\u2086\n  \u2013 M_{BC}: detectors d\u2087,d\u2088\n  \u2013 M_{CD}: detectors d\u2089,d\u2081\u2080\n\nPost\u2010selection: one click pair in each module\u2019s detectors heralds success in that branch. Because the interferometer places the photons in a superposition of \u201cforward\u201d vs. \u201cbackward\u201d routing orders, the final spins Q_A & Q_D become entangled via an indefinite\u2010order swapping supermap. This is a higher\u2010order network operation, not mere state generation.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u2194p\u2081)] [S\u2082:(1\u2194p\u2082)] [S\u2083:(2\u2194p\u2083)] [S\u2084:(3\u2194p\u2084)]  \ncircuit:     [4\u00d74 symmetric multiport routing p\u2081\u2013p\u2084 into M_{AB},M_{BC},M_{CD} in superposition of two sequences]  \nswap modules:\n             M_{AB} \u2192 anc5, anc6  \n             M_{BC} \u2192 anc7, anc8  \n             M_{CD} \u2192 anc9, anc10  \ndetectors:   [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][spin\u2010read@3][anc5]...[anc10]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"Indefinite\u2010order entanglement\u2010swap switch for Q_A\u2013Q_D\",\n  foldername          : \"indef_swap_switch\",\n  edges_tried         : 40,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 6,                  # detectors 5\u201310\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 15,\n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],        # final Bell on Q_A & Q_D\n  in_nodes            : [],\n  out_nodes           : [0,3],\n  single_emitters     : [],\n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],                  \n  anc_detectors       : [5,6,7,8,9,10],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2013 Extend to N swapping channels (higher\u2010order supermaps).  \n \u2013 Explore indefinite causal orders in larger networks (e.g. superposition of looped swapping vs. linear swapping).  \n \u2013 Paves the way for experimental studies of quantum supermaps on chip.\n\nThis target fuses coherent light\u2013matter sources with a passive integrated photonic super\u2010interferometer to realize, for the first time in a quantum\u2010optics experiment, indefinite causal order of multiple entanglement\u2010distribution channels."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. By routing ancilla photons through a static 4\u00d74 multipath interferometer to erase which-swap information and postselecting on four-click coincidences, we realize in one shot the coherent entanglement routing across all pairing geometries.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Four-Party GHZ Entanglement-Swapping Star with 3\u21921 Network Steering\n\nAbstract: We implement a single-step four-photon GHZ entanglement-swapping star that fuses four independent probabilistic Bell-pair sources at a central station via a linear-optical 4-photon GHZ projector to realize the target 4-party GHZ resource. Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \n\u201cCyclic-Graph Teleportation with Passive Pauli Cancellation and Measurement-Controlled Phase Gate\u201d\n\nAbstract  \nWe implement a static linear-optical protocol that teleports an unknown qubit from Alice (mode 0) to Bob (mode 3) by entangling four probabilistic Bell pairs into a cycle graph, passively canceling all Pauli by-products and embedding a measurement-controlled Z-rotation on the teleported state without any active feed-forward. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Tree Tensor Network Classifier for Four-Qubit Boolean Functions in PytHeus\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a depth-2 photonic Tree Tensor Network (TTN) isometry that cascades two levels of entanglement-swapping modules to map four input qubits (leaves) onto a single output qubit (root), explicitly targeting the Boolean classification f(x0,x1,x2,x3). Implemented in the PytHeus framework, our scheme uses only probabilistic photon-pair sources, tunable beam-splitter reflectivities, ancilla detectors, and removed_connection constraints to enforce the binary-tree topology without dynamic feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid Concentration-Swap of Two Qutrit Bell Pairs into One Qubit Bell Pair\n\nAbstract: We introduce a heralded linear-optical protocol that concentrates two independent three-level (qutrit) Bell pairs into a single two-level (qubit) Bell pair by mixing the local qutrit halves with ancillary single-photon modes and photon-number-resolving detection at the central node. Upon a specific four-click detection pattern, the unmeasured remote modes collapse into the target qubit Bell state, achieving the conversion from two qutrit Bell pairs to one qubit Bell pair.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Mid\u2010Gap Bell\u2010Pair Extraction in a Dimerized Photonic SSH Repeater Chain  \n\nMini\u2010abstract:  \nWe implement a linear\u2010optical SSH chain of 2M+1 spatial modes using alternating strong (two\u2010pair) and weak (single\u2010pair) photon sources, performing heralded Bell\u2010state measurements at each non\u2010central node. Conditioned on a specific four-ancilla photon click pattern, the remaining three photons enact the Fredkin truth table\u2014swapping the two polarization target qubits only when the control photon is in the logical |1\u27e9 state\u2014without any dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Non-Destructive QND Measurement of Photon-Number Difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND via Mode-Squeezed Ancillas\n\nMini-Abstract: We introduce a PyTheus network primitive that non-destructively measures the photon-number difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND between two distant Fock-encoded modes A and D by mixing each with one arm of a two-mode squeezed ancilla at static beam splitters and post-selecting on the ancilla detector difference outcome k. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a fully specified target for Pytheus\u2014an on-chip, post-selected entanglement swap between two matter qubits mediated by an integrated photonic Bell-state analyzer.\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider two stationary spin qubits (e.g. quantum-dot exciton levels) on an integrated photonic chip, labelled nodes 0 and 1. Each spin is initially entangled with an emitted photon via a coherent light\u2013matter interaction on chip, realizing two independent Bell pairs:\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2081 emits an abstract Bell state between spin-mode 0 and photonic mode 2.\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2082 emits an identical Bell state between spin-mode 1 and photonic mode 3.\nThe two photons (modes 2 & 3) are routed by an integrated waveguide circuit into a linear-optics Bell-state measurement (BSM) block (a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifters). Successful BSM outcomes are heralded by two ancillary detectors (modes 4 & 5). Conditioned on a click in each ancilla detector (post-selection), the two remote spins (nodes 0 & 1) collapse into a maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates photonic-mediated entanglement swapping of matter qubits on chip.\n\nVisualization (modes going top\u2192bottom):\nemitters: [ S\u2081: (0\u21942) ]  [ S\u2082: (1\u21943) ]  \ncircuit: [ waveguide routing 2 & 3 into 50:50 BS + phase shifter network ]  \ndetectors: [spin-readout@0][spin-readout@1][detector@2][detector@3][ancilla@4][ancilla@5]\n\nKey points:\n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward: success is post-selected by ancilla clicks.\n  \u2013 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction enters via the two initial Bell-pair sources.\n  \u2013 Entire Bell-measurement circuit and routing is realized in an integrated photonic waveguide architecture.\n  \u2013 The target is the abstract transformation: two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 post-selected spin\u2013spin Bell pair (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9).\n  \u2013 This protocol can be generalized to multiple nodes (linear repeater chains or networks with star/topologies).\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description: \"On-chip entanglement swapping between two spin qubits via photonic Bell-measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hybrid_spin_swap\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],        # spin nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes: [],                       # pair sources define inputs\n  out_nodes: [0,1],\n  heralding_out: null,\n  single_emitters: [],                # abstract pair sources instead\n  amplitudes: [],\n  removed_connections: [],            # allow all routing\n  anc_detectors: [4,5],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal essentially describes a standard entanglement\u2010swapping protocol\u2014two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs followed by a photonic Bell measurement yielding a spin\u2013spin Bell pair\u2014but merely implemented in an on\u2010chip waveguide circuit. Such spin\u2013photon mediated entanglement swapping has already been demonstrated in NV centers, quantum dots, and other platforms (e.g. Moehring et al. Nature 2007; Bernien et al. Nature 2013), and integrated photonic Bell analyzers are well\u2010explored. There is no new foundational feature, multi-node network effect, or higher-dimensional twist that would elevate this to PRL novelty.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too close to existing spin\u2013photon entanglement-swapping experiments and on-chip Bell analyzers. To be novel at the PRL level, you would need to introduce a genuinely new element\u2014e.g. an indefinite\u2010order swap, a heralded multi-qubit fusion primitive that cannot be reduced to standard swapping, or integration of nonclassical ancilla conservation that goes beyond straightforward photonic routing.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target configuration\u2014an integrated \u201cquantum\u2010router\u201d that teleports a spin\u2010qubit from node A to B or C in coherent superposition, heralded by post-selected photonic detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label three stationary spin qubits on chip: A (mode 0), B (mode 1), C (mode 2). Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each produce an abstract Bell pair:\n  \u2022 S\u2081: entangles spin A (0) with photonic mode 3.  \n  \u2022 S\u2082: entangles spin B (1) with photonic mode 4.  \n  \u2022 S\u2083: entangles spin C (2) with photonic mode 5.  \n\nWe wish to teleport an arbitrary input state |\u03c8\u27e9 on spin A to either B or C, but in a controlled superposition. We build an integrated photonic circuit that routes mode 3 equally into two Bell\u2010measurement blocks:\n  \u2013 Block 1 jointly measures modes (3 & 4) to teleport to B.\n  \u2013 Block 2 jointly measures modes (3 & 5) to teleport to C.\n\nA 50:50 directional coupler splits mode 3 into paths to both blocks; the two Bell\u2010analyzers are realized with beam splitters and phase shifters on chip. Each block has two ancilla detectors (modes 6,7 for B-branch and modes 8,9 for C-branch). A pair of clicks in either the B-branch detectors or the C-branch detectors heralds successful teleportation to B or C, respectively\u2014but because the split was coherent, the teleportation destination remains in superposition until detection. The final abstract mapping is:\n\n  |\u03c8\u27e9_A \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{B4} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{C5}\n    \u2192 ( |\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{6,7} + |\u03c8\u27e9_C\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{8,9} )\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21943)]  [S\u2082:(1\u21944)]  [S\u2083:(2\u21945)]  \ncircuit:    [split 3 \u2192 path to Bell-analyzer(3,4) + Bell-analyzer(3,5)]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][anc6][anc7][anc8][anc9]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description       : \"On\u2010chip superposition\u2010of\u2010destinations quantum router via post\u2010selected teleportation\",\n  foldername        : \"quantum_router_teleport\",\n  edges_tried       : 30,\n  ftol              : 1e-06,\n  loss_func         : \"cr\",\n  num_anc           : 4,            # detectors 6,7,8,9\n  optimizer         : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples           : 12,\n  target_quantum    : [\"0B\",\"1B\",\"0C\",\"1C\"], # abstract mapping onto spin B or C\n  in_nodes          : [],\n  out_nodes         : [1,2,6,7,8,9], \n  single_emitters   : [],\n  amplitudes        : [],\n  removed_connections: [],          # allow all beam\u2010splitter couplings\n  anc_detectors     : [6,7,8,9],\n  number_resolving  : true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Can be extended to N output nodes by splitting into N Bell blocks.  \n  \u2013 Forms a building block for photonic\u2010mediated quantum networks on a chip: coherent routing primitives beyond fixed\u2010path swapping.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a spin\u2010qubit version of the \u201cdual\u2010destination teleportation switch\u201d already in the ensemble list (see \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\u201d). Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each generate a (noisy) abstract Bell pair:\n \u2022 S\u2081 produces entanglement between spin 0 and photon mode 2.  \n \u2022 S\u2082 produces entanglement between spin 1 and photon mode 3.  \n\nThese two raw spin\u2013photon Bell pairs suffer dephasing or imperfect fidelity. We wish to purify them into a single higher\u2010fidelity spin\u2013spin Bell pair on nodes 0&1. To do so, we interfere the two photons (modes 2,3) in an integrated parity\u2010check circuit: a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifter network that effectively implements a photonic parity measurement. Two number\u2010resolving detectors (modes 4 & 5) herald a successful even\u2010parity outcome. Conditioned on one click in each detector (post\u2010selection), the remaining spins collapse into a purified Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates on\u2010chip entanglement purification of matter qubit memories.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21942)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21943)]  \nparity\u2010circuit:  [BS(2,3) + phase network]  \ndetectors:   [spin-read@0][spin-read@1][anc@4][anc@5]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"On-chip entanglement purification of two spin qubits via photonic parity check\",\n  foldername          : \"spin_purification_chip\",\n  edges_tried         : 25,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 2,               # detectors 4 & 5\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 10,\n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],     # purified spin pair on nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [0,1],\n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [4,5],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2013 Cascaded purification: chain multiple rounds by feeding in additional raw pairs.  \n \u2013 Multipartite purification: extend to three or more spins via multi-photon parity checks.  \n \u2013 Forms a building block for on-chip error mitigation in scalable photonic\u2013matter quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The on\u2010chip spin\u2010qubit entanglement purification via a simple photonic parity check is essentially the direct Bennett\u2010style two\u2010pair parity\u2010filter purification protocol ported to matter qubits. The integrated photonic circuit implements the butterfly network coding: it combines photons 4 & 5 on a 50:50 coupler, splits outputs into two arms, and then each arm interferes with photon 6 or 7 in a Bell\u2010measurement block. Two pairs of ancilla detectors (modes 8&9 for R\u2081\u2010branch, 10&11 for R\u2082\u2010branch) herald successful network\u2010coded teleportation events. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"coherent light matter interaction\" and \"integrated photonic circuit\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Successful BSM outcomes are heralded by two ancillary detectors (modes 4 & 5). This demonstrates photonic-mediated entanglement swapping of matter qubits on chip.\n\nVisualization (modes going top\u2192bottom):\nemitters: [ S\u2081: (0\u21942) ]  [ S\u2082: (1\u21943) ]  \ncircuit: [ waveguide routing 2 & 3 into 50:50 BS + phase shifter network ]  \ndetectors: [spin-readout@0][spin-readout@1][detector@2][detector@3][ancilla@4][ancilla@5]\n\nKey points:\n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward: success is post-selected by ancilla clicks.\n  \u2013 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction enters via the two initial Bell-pair sources.\n  \u2013 Entire Bell-measurement circuit and routing is realized in an integrated photonic waveguide architecture.\n  \u2013 The target is the abstract transformation: two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 post-selected spin\u2013spin Bell pair (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9).\n  \u2013 This protocol can be generalized to multiple nodes (linear repeater chains or networks with star/topologies).\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description: \"On-chip entanglement swapping between two spin qubits via photonic Bell-measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hybrid_spin_swap\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],        # spin nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes: [],                       # pair sources define inputs\n  out_nodes: [0,1],\n  heralding_out: null,\n  single_emitters: [],                # abstract pair sources instead\n  amplitudes: [],\n  removed_connections: [],            # allow all routing\n  anc_detectors: [4,5],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to existing spin\u2013photon entanglement-swapping experiments and on-chip Bell analyzers. Three coherent light\u2013matter interfaces produce three abstract Bell pairs:\n  \u2022 S\u2081: entangles qubit A (0) with photonic mode 3.  \n  \u2022 S\u2082: entangles qubit B (1) with photonic mode 4.  \n  \u2022 S\u2083: entangles qubit C (2) with photonic mode 5.  \n\nWe wish to teleport an unknown state |\u03c8\u27e9 from A into a coherent superposition of B and C. Photonic mode 3 is passed through an integrated 50:50 splitter that routes it equally into two Bell\u2010analyzer blocks:\n  \u2013 Block B: joint Bell measurement on modes (3\u2081,4) to teleport to B, heralded by clicks in ancilla detectors 6 & 7.\n  \u2013 Block C: joint Bell measurement on modes (3\u2082,5) to teleport to C, heralded by clicks in ancilla detectors 8 & 9.\n\nBecause the splitter acts coherently, a successful pair of clicks in {6,7} vs. {8,9} projects the final state to |\u03c8\u27e9 at B or at C\u2014but before detection the destination is in superposition. The overall abstract post\u2010selected mapping is:\n\n  |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080 \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{1,4} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{2,5}\n    \u2192 ( |\u03c8\u27e9\u2081 \u2297 |clicks\u27e9_{6,7} + |\u03c8\u27e9\u2082 \u2297 |clicks\u27e9_{8,9} ).\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21943)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21944)]   [S\u2083:(2\u21945)]  \ncircuit:    [split 3 \u2192 two Bell blocks on (3,4) and (3,5)]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][anc6][anc7][anc8][anc9]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"Quantum\u2010router: coherent superposition teleportation A\u2192{B,C}\",\n  foldername          : \"quantum_router_teleport\",\n  edges_tried         : 30,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 4,             # ancillas 6,7,8,9\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 12,\n  target_quantum      : [\"\u03c8@1+\u03c8@2\"],   # abstract superposition target on modes 1&2 conditioned on ancillas\n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [1,2],  \n  heralding_out       : null,\n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],  \n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [6,7,8,9],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N possible destinations by splitting into N Bell\u2010analyzers.  \n  \u2013 Forms a new primitive for coherent routing in integrated photonic quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the known dual\u2010destination teleportation switch without substantive innovation. To reach PRL novelty, you must introduce a genuinely new element\u2014such as nontrivial causal superposition, a multi\u2010party fusion primitive, or a higher\u2010dimensional routing capability\u2014that cannot be reduced to standard teleportation routing.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! We wish to purify them into a single higher\u2010fidelity spin\u2013spin Bell pair on nodes 0&1. To do so, we interfere the two photons (modes 2,3) in an integrated parity\u2010check circuit: a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifter network that effectively implements a photonic parity measurement. Two number\u2010resolving detectors (modes 4 & 5) herald a successful even\u2010parity outcome. Conditioned on one click in each detector (post\u2010selection), the remaining spins collapse into a purified Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates on\u2010chip entanglement purification of matter qubit memories.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21942)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21943)]  \nparity\u2010circuit:  [BS(2,3) + phase network]  \ndetectors:   [spin-read@0][spin-read@1][anc@4][anc@5]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"On-chip entanglement purification of two spin qubits via photonic parity check\",\n  foldername          : \"spin_purification_chip\",\n  edges_tried         : 25,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 2,               # detectors 4 & 5\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 10,\n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],     # purified spin pair on nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [0,1],\n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [4,5],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2013 Cascaded purification: chain multiple rounds by feeding in additional raw pairs.  \n \u2013 Multipartite purification: extend to three or more spins via multi-photon parity checks.  \n \u2013 Forms a building block for on-chip error mitigation in scalable photonic\u2013matter quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to known entanglement purification protocols (including on-chip qutrit purification and passive Bell-filter networks) and offers no fundamentally new element.
