    "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm 3 Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to merge \u201ccoherent light\u2013matter interaction\u201d and \u201cintegrated photonic circuit\u201d into a network protocol (no na\u00efve state generation):\n    1. On\u2010chip entanglement\u2010purification + swapping repeater node.\n    2. Superposition\u2010of\u2010destinations teleportation (\u201cquantum router\u201d).\n    3. Coherent\u2010multiplexed entanglement percolation: two parallel spin\u2010qubit swap channels are placed in quantum superposition via integrated beam splitters, demonstrating percolation\u2010style entanglement distribution in a square network.\n  Step 2: Feasibility & novelty:\n    1 & 2 have appeared in various forms and been critiqued as too close to known primitives.\n    3 is genuinely new for Pytheus: it realizes an entanglement\u2010percolation network in a coherent, multiplexed fashion\u2014each spin\u2013photon Bell source is split onto two swap channels in superposition, and integrated BSM blocks at the two intermediate nodes post\u2010selectively herald entanglement between distant spins. It combines light\u2013matter pair sources and a passive integrated circuit, no feedback.\n  Step 3: Choose idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty: No previous Pytheus target has implemented coherent superposition of two parallel entanglement\u2010swap routes to realize a percolation\u2010style network distribution.\n  Step 5: Feasible in Pytheus: uses only abstract Bell\u2010pair sources (coherent light\u2013matter interfaces), 50:50 couplers and phase shifters (integrated photonic circuit), and number\u2010resolving detectors for post\u2010selection\u2014no cavities or dynamic control needed.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014an on\u2010chip, coherent\u2010multiplexed entanglement\u2010percolation experiment for four spin\u2010qubit nodes in a square network, combining coherent light\u2013matter pair sources with an integrated photonic circuit:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label four stationary spin\u2010qubit nodes on chip:\n  \u2022 A (mode 0)  \n  \u2022 B (mode 1)  \n  \u2022 C (mode 2)  \n  \u2022 D (mode 3)\n\nFour coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each emit an abstract Bell pair between a spin node and its emitted photon:\n  S\u2081: Q_A(0) \u2194 p\u2081(4)  \n  S\u2082: Q_B(1) \u2194 p\u2082(5)  \n  S\u2083: Q_C(2) \u2194 p\u2083(6)  \n  S\u2084: Q_D(3) \u2194 p\u2084(7)\n\nThese four photons are each sent into a 50:50 on\u2010chip directional coupler that coherently splits p_j \u2192 {p_j\u2090,\u200ap_j_b}. The \u201c\u2090\u201d outputs route to the Bell\u2010measurement block at intermediate node B, and the \u201c_b\u201d outputs route to the Bell\u2010measurement block at node C. Each Bell\u2010block is a standard linear\u2010optics Bell\u2010analyzer (50:50 BS + phases) acting on two photons:\n  \u2013 Block B measures (p\u2081\u2090,p\u2082\u2090) and (p\u2083\u2090,p\u2084\u2090), with ancilla detectors at modes 8,9,10,11.  \n  \u2013 Block C measures (p\u2081_b,p\u2082_b) and (p\u2083_b,p\u2084_b), with ancilla detectors at modes 12,13,14,15.\n\nBecause of the coherent splitting, the two possible swap\u2010paths (A\u2013B\u2013D via B or A\u2013C\u2013D via C) are in quantum superposition. A successful round of entanglement distribution is heralded by detecting one click\u2010pair in either Block B\u2019s ancillas or Block C\u2019s ancillas (post\u2010selection). Conditioned on that herald, spins A (0) and D (3) collapse into a Bell pair, demonstrating entanglement percolation with coherent multiplexing.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21944)]  [S\u2082:(1\u21945)]  [S\u2083:(2\u21946)]  [S\u2084:(3\u21947)]  \nsplitters:   [split 4\u21924\u2090,4_b; 5\u21925\u2090,5_b; 6\u21926\u2090,6_b; 7\u21927\u2090,7_b]  \nBell-blocks: [BS on (4\u2090,5\u2090) & (6\u2090,7\u2090) \u2192 anc8\u201311]  \n             [BS on (4_b,5_b) & (6_b,7_b) \u2192 anc12\u201315]  \ndetectors:   [spin-read@0][spin-read@1][spin-read@2][spin-read@3]\n             [anc8\u2026anc15]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"Coherent\u2010multiplexed entanglement percolation on a square network\",\n  foldername          : \"ent_percolation_multiplex\",\n  edges_tried         : 30,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 8,             # detectors 8\u201315\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 12,\n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],   # final Bell on Q_A(0) & Q_D(3)\n  in_nodes            : [],\n  out_nodes           : [0,3],\n  single_emitters     : [],\n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],\n  anc_detectors       : [8,9,10,11,12,13,14,15],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nKey Points:\n \u2022 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction is realized by the four spin\u2013photon Bell\u2010pair sources.  \n \u2022 Integrated photonic circuit implements passive 50:50 splitters and two Bell\u2010analyzer blocks\u2014no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.  \n \u2022 Heralding patterns in either Bell\u2010block enact entanglement swapping along one of two parallel routes; because of the initial splitting, the choice is in quantum superposition, showcasing coherent percolation.  \n \u2022 This protocol is readily generalizable to larger lattices (triangular, honeycomb) to study percolation thresholds, and to higher dimensions or multiplexed networks.\n\nThis target introduces a fundamentally new network transformation\u2014coherently multiplexed entanglement\u2010percolation\u2014bridging coherent light\u2013matter interfaces with integrated photonics in a Pytheus\u2010compatible experiment."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. By reprogramming only the EOM voltages\u2014while leaving the linear-optical network unchanged\u2014the same device can project onto the W basis or any rotated three-qubit entangled basis, opening new avenues for adaptive entanglement swapping, secret sharing, and fundamental tests of nonlocality.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. By routing ancilla photons through a static 4\u00d74 multipath interferometer to erase which-swap information and postselecting on four-click coincidences, we realize in one shot the coherent entanglement routing across all pairing geometries.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Four-Party GHZ Entanglement-Swapping Star with 3\u21921 Network Steering\n\nAbstract: We implement a single-step four-photon GHZ entanglement-swapping star that fuses four independent probabilistic Bell-pair sources at a central station via a linear-optical 4-photon GHZ projector to realize the target 4-party GHZ resource. Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \n\u201cCyclic-Graph Teleportation with Passive Pauli Cancellation and Measurement-Controlled Phase Gate\u201d\n\nAbstract  \nWe implement a static linear-optical protocol that teleports an unknown qubit from Alice (mode 0) to Bob (mode 3) by entangling four probabilistic Bell pairs into a cycle graph, passively canceling all Pauli by-products and embedding a measurement-controlled Z-rotation on the teleported state without any active feed-forward. Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Tree Tensor Network Classifier for Four-Qubit Boolean Functions in PytHeus\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a depth-2 photonic Tree Tensor Network (TTN) isometry that cascades two levels of entanglement-swapping modules to map four input qubits (leaves) onto a single output qubit (root), explicitly targeting the Boolean classification f(x0,x1,x2,x3). Implemented in the PytHeus framework, our scheme uses only probabilistic photon-pair sources, tunable beam-splitter reflectivities, ancilla detectors, and removed_connection constraints to enforce the binary-tree topology without dynamic feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid Concentration-Swap of Two Qutrit Bell Pairs into One Qubit Bell Pair\n\nAbstract: We introduce a heralded linear-optical protocol that concentrates two independent three-level (qutrit) Bell pairs into a single two-level (qubit) Bell pair by mixing the local qutrit halves with ancillary single-photon modes and photon-number-resolving detection at the central node. Upon a specific four-click detection pattern, the unmeasured remote modes collapse into the target qubit Bell state, achieving the conversion from two qutrit Bell pairs to one qubit Bell pair.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Mid\u2010Gap Bell\u2010Pair Extraction in a Dimerized Photonic SSH Repeater Chain  \n\nMini\u2010abstract:  \nWe implement a linear\u2010optical SSH chain of 2M+1 spatial modes using alternating strong (two\u2010pair) and weak (single\u2010pair) photon sources, performing heralded Bell\u2010state measurements at each non\u2010central node.  Post\u2010selection on successful heralds yields a mid\u2010gap Bell pair at the central outputs only in the topological configuration, directly probing the chain\u2019s photonic mid\u2010gap entanglement and demonstrating its robustness against weak\u2010bond failure.Title: Programmable Photonic VQA for GHZ vs W Tripartite Entanglement Certification\n\nMini-abstract: We introduce a PyTheus-designed linear-optical interferometer with tunable beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors, trained via a classical variational loop to classify unknown three-qubit photonic inputs as GHZ-class or W-class states. This protocol explicitly targets the certification of genuine multipartite entanglement structure in photonic systems and can be implemented on current programmable photonic hardware.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Programmable Teleportation of CNOT and SWAP Gates onto Two Neutral-Atom Qubits\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a fixed interferometer module that, depending on the internal state of a control atom (C) and heralding detector clicks, teleports either a CNOT\u208dA\u2192B\u208e or SWAP\u208dA\u2194B\u208e gate onto two remote target neutral-atom qubits A and B. Relying solely on single-emitter photons, probabilistic ancilla, linear optics and number-resolving heralds\u2014without cavities or active feed-forward\u2014this scheme realizes pure quantum-network transformations and is directly extensible to larger gate sets and control registers.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superactivation-Assisted Entanglement Distribution Under Amplitude Damping\n\nAbstract: We propose an experiment in which two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources generate Bell pairs on modes (0,1) and (2,3), and modes 1 & 2 traverse amplitude\u2010damped channels modeled by beam splitters coupling into ancilla modes 4 & 5. Instead of discarding these ancillas, a fixed Bell\u2010type measurement on three ancilla detectors (6,7,8) \u201cunlocks\u201d a Bell component (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2 on the target modes 0 and 3\u2014even for damping rates that individually preclude entanglement\u2014thereby directly probing resource\u2010theoretic superactivation in a minimal linear\u2010optics network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Measurement-Based Fredkin Gate on Polarization-Encoded Target Qubits\n\nMini-abstract: We present a purely linear-optical, heralded implementation of the Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate in which a \u201ccorner-mode\u201d single-photon qubit serves as control and two polarization-encoded photons serve as the explicit swap targets. Conditioned on a specific four-ancilla photon click pattern, the remaining three photons enact the Fredkin truth table\u2014swapping the two polarization target qubits only when the control photon is in the logical |1\u27e9 state\u2014without any dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Non-Destructive QND Measurement of Photon-Number Difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND via Mode-Squeezed Ancillas\n\nMini-Abstract: We introduce a PyTheus network primitive that non-destructively measures the photon-number difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND between two distant Fock-encoded modes A and D by mixing each with one arm of a two-mode squeezed ancilla at static beam splitters and post-selecting on the ancilla detector difference outcome k. This scheme infers the target \u0394N without disturbing modes A and D, providing a distributed QND observable extraction for syndrome readout and error checking across network nodes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Sequential Non-Demolition Qutrit Measurement Network for KCBS Contextuality via Tunable Ancilla Coupling\n\nMini-abstract: We target a sequential nondestructive qutrit measurement network for KCBS contextuality with tunable ultrastrong-coupling ancillas, implementing the five-node pentagon test by entangling a single-photon qutrit with five ancilla photons through beam splitters of adjustable reflectivity R\u2081\u2026R\u2085. By sweeping each R\u1d62 from \u00bd (weak, unsharp) to 1 (ultrastrong, near-projective) coupling, we realize a genuine measurement-induced quantum network primitive and systematically explore how KCBS inequality violations survive under partial-strength sequential measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIntegrated Photonic Quantum Teleportation Router with On-Chip Delay Cavities  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate the target \u201cQuantum Teleportation Router with On-Chip Delay Cavities\u201d by coherently splitting an unknown single-photon qubit at node A and teleporting it, via two independent probabilistic entangled-pair sources and synchronized on-chip delay loops, onto two remote outputs at nodes B and C. Post-selecting a fixed Bell outcome in each Bell-state measurement and employing only passive 50:50 beam splitters, fixed delay cavities, ancilla detectors, and single-photon emitters realizes a genuine quantum routing primitive that maps |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 \u2192 (|\u03c8\u27e9\u1d66 + |\u03c8\u27e9\ud835\udcb8)/\u221a2 without feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a fully specified target for Pytheus\u2014an on-chip, post-selected entanglement swap between two matter qubits mediated by an integrated photonic Bell-state analyzer.\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider two stationary spin qubits (e.g. quantum-dot exciton levels) on an integrated photonic chip, labelled nodes 0 and 1. Each spin is initially entangled with an emitted photon via a coherent light\u2013matter interaction on chip, realizing two independent Bell pairs:\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2081 emits an abstract Bell state between spin-mode 0 and photonic mode 2.\n  \u2022 Pair-source S\u2082 emits an identical Bell state between spin-mode 1 and photonic mode 3.\nThe two photons (modes 2 & 3) are routed by an integrated waveguide circuit into a linear-optics Bell-state measurement (BSM) block (a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifters). Successful BSM outcomes are heralded by two ancillary detectors (modes 4 & 5). Conditioned on a click in each ancilla detector (post-selection), the two remote spins (nodes 0 & 1) collapse into a maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates photonic-mediated entanglement swapping of matter qubits on chip.\n\nVisualization (modes going top\u2192bottom):\nemitters: [ S\u2081: (0\u21942) ]  [ S\u2082: (1\u21943) ]  \ncircuit: [ waveguide routing 2 & 3 into 50:50 BS + phase shifter network ]  \ndetectors: [spin-readout@0][spin-readout@1][detector@2][detector@3][ancilla@4][ancilla@5]\n\nKey points:\n  \u2013 No dynamic feed-forward: success is post-selected by ancilla clicks.\n  \u2013 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction enters via the two initial Bell-pair sources.\n  \u2013 Entire Bell-measurement circuit and routing is realized in an integrated photonic waveguide architecture.\n  \u2013 The target is the abstract transformation: two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs \u2192 post-selected spin\u2013spin Bell pair (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9).\n  \u2013 This protocol can be generalized to multiple nodes (linear repeater chains or networks with star/topologies).\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description: \"On-chip entanglement swapping between two spin qubits via photonic Bell-measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hybrid_spin_swap\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],        # spin nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes: [],                       # pair sources define inputs\n  out_nodes: [0,1],\n  heralding_out: null,\n  single_emitters: [],                # abstract pair sources instead\n  amplitudes: [],\n  removed_connections: [],            # allow all routing\n  anc_detectors: [4,5],\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal essentially describes a standard entanglement\u2010swapping protocol\u2014two spin\u2013photon Bell pairs followed by a photonic Bell measurement yielding a spin\u2013spin Bell pair\u2014but merely implemented in an on\u2010chip waveguide circuit. Such spin\u2013photon mediated entanglement swapping has already been demonstrated in NV centers, quantum dots, and other platforms (e.g. Moehring et al. Nature 2007; Bernien et al. Nature 2013), and integrated photonic Bell analyzers are well\u2010explored. There is no new foundational feature, multi-node network effect, or higher-dimensional twist that would elevate this to PRL novelty.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too close to existing spin\u2013photon entanglement-swapping experiments and on-chip Bell analyzers. To be novel at the PRL level, you would need to introduce a genuinely new element\u2014e.g. an indefinite\u2010order swap, a heralded multi-qubit fusion primitive that cannot be reduced to standard swapping, or integration of nonclassical ancilla conservation that goes beyond straightforward photonic routing.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target configuration\u2014an integrated \u201cquantum\u2010router\u201d that teleports a spin\u2010qubit from node A to B or C in coherent superposition, heralded by post-selected photonic detection:\n\nExplanation:\nWe label three stationary spin qubits on chip: A (mode 0), B (mode 1), C (mode 2). Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each produce an abstract Bell pair:\n  \u2022 S\u2081: entangles spin A (0) with photonic mode 3.  \n  \u2022 S\u2082: entangles spin B (1) with photonic mode 4.  \n  \u2022 S\u2083: entangles spin C (2) with photonic mode 5.  \n\nWe wish to teleport an arbitrary input state |\u03c8\u27e9 on spin A to either B or C, but in a controlled superposition. We build an integrated photonic circuit that routes mode 3 equally into two Bell\u2010measurement blocks:\n  \u2013 Block 1 jointly measures modes (3 & 4) to teleport to B.\n  \u2013 Block 2 jointly measures modes (3 & 5) to teleport to C.\n\nA 50:50 directional coupler splits mode 3 into paths to both blocks; the two Bell\u2010analyzers are realized with beam splitters and phase shifters on chip. Each block has two ancilla detectors (modes 6,7 for B-branch and modes 8,9 for C-branch). A pair of clicks in either the B-branch detectors or the C-branch detectors heralds successful teleportation to B or C, respectively\u2014but because the split was coherent, the teleportation destination remains in superposition until detection. The final abstract mapping is:\n\n  |\u03c8\u27e9_A \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{B4} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{C5}\n    \u2192 ( |\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{6,7} + |\u03c8\u27e9_C\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{8,9} )\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21943)]  [S\u2082:(1\u21944)]  [S\u2083:(2\u21945)]  \ncircuit:    [split 3 \u2192 path to Bell-analyzer(3,4) + Bell-analyzer(3,5)]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][anc6][anc7][anc8][anc9]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description       : \"On\u2010chip superposition\u2010of\u2010destinations quantum router via post\u2010selected teleportation\",\n  foldername        : \"quantum_router_teleport\",\n  edges_tried       : 30,\n  ftol              : 1e-06,\n  loss_func         : \"cr\",\n  num_anc           : 4,            # detectors 6,7,8,9\n  optimizer         : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples           : 12,\n  target_quantum    : [\"0B\",\"1B\",\"0C\",\"1C\"], # abstract mapping onto spin B or C\n  in_nodes          : [],\n  out_nodes         : [1,2,6,7,8,9], \n  single_emitters   : [],\n  amplitudes        : [],\n  removed_connections: [],          # allow all beam\u2010splitter couplings\n  anc_detectors     : [6,7,8,9],\n  number_resolving  : true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Can be extended to N output nodes by splitting into N Bell blocks.  \n  \u2013 Forms a building block for photonic\u2010mediated quantum networks on a chip: coherent routing primitives beyond fixed\u2010path swapping.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a spin\u2010qubit version of the \u201cdual\u2010destination teleportation switch\u201d already in the ensemble list (see \u201cDual\u2010Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\u201d). Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each generate a (noisy) abstract Bell pair:\n \u2022 S\u2081 produces entanglement between spin 0 and photon mode 2.  \n \u2022 S\u2082 produces entanglement between spin 1 and photon mode 3.  \n\nThese two raw spin\u2013photon Bell pairs suffer dephasing or imperfect fidelity. We wish to purify them into a single higher\u2010fidelity spin\u2013spin Bell pair on nodes 0&1. To do so, we interfere the two photons (modes 2,3) in an integrated parity\u2010check circuit: a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifter network that effectively implements a photonic parity measurement. Two number\u2010resolving detectors (modes 4 & 5) herald a successful even\u2010parity outcome. Conditioned on one click in each detector (post\u2010selection), the remaining spins collapse into a purified Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates on\u2010chip entanglement purification of matter qubit memories.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21942)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21943)]  \nparity\u2010circuit:  [BS(2,3) + phase network]  \ndetectors:   [spin-read@0][spin-read@1][anc@4][anc@5]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"On-chip entanglement purification of two spin qubits via photonic parity check\",\n  foldername          : \"spin_purification_chip\",\n  edges_tried         : 25,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 2,               # detectors 4 & 5\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 10,\n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],     # purified spin pair on nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [0,1],\n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [4,5],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2013 Cascaded purification: chain multiple rounds by feeding in additional raw pairs.  \n \u2013 Multipartite purification: extend to three or more spins via multi-photon parity checks.  \n \u2013 Forms a building block for on-chip error mitigation in scalable photonic\u2013matter quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The on\u2010chip spin\u2010qubit entanglement purification via a simple photonic parity check is essentially the direct Bennett\u2010style two\u2010pair parity\u2010filter purification protocol ported to matter qubits. The integrated photonic circuit implements the butterfly network coding: it combines photons 4 & 5 on a 50:50 coupler, splits outputs into two arms, and then each arm interferes with photon 6 or 7 in a Bell\u2010measurement block. Two pairs of ancilla detectors (modes 8&9 for R\u2081\u2010branch, 10&11 for R\u2082\u2010branch) herald successful network\u2010coded teleportation events. The \u201c\u2090\u201d outputs route to the Bell\u2010measurement block at intermediate node B, and the \u201c_b\u201d outputs route to the Bell\u2010measurement block at node C. Each Bell\u2010block is a standard linear\u2010optics Bell\u2010analyzer (50:50 BS + phases) acting on two photons:\n  \u2013 Block B measures (p\u2081\u2090,p\u2082\u2090) and (p\u2083\u2090,p\u2084\u2090), with ancilla detectors at modes 8,9,10,11.  \n  \u2013 Block C measures (p\u2081_b,p\u2082_b) and (p\u2083_b,p\u2084_b), with ancilla detectors at modes 12,13,14,15.\n\nBecause of the coherent splitting, the two possible swap\u2010paths (A\u2013B\u2013D via B or A\u2013C\u2013D via C) are in quantum superposition.     "output": "Thought: This is essentially just spatially multiplexed entanglement swapping\u2014two parallel swap paths (A\u2013B\u2013D vs. A\u2013C\u2013D) with a passive splitter and post-selective Bell measurements\u2014matching \u201cPassive Spatial-Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping on a Nanoscale Waveguide Chip\u201d (ensemble).     "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. Successful BSM outcomes are heralded by two ancillary detectors (modes 4 & 5). Conditioned on a click in each ancilla detector (post-selection), the two remote spins (nodes 0 & 1) collapse into a maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each produce an abstract Bell pair:\n  \u2022 S\u2081: entangles spin A (0) with photonic mode 3.  \n  \u2022 S\u2082: entangles spin B (1) with photonic mode 4.  \n  \u2022 S\u2083: entangles spin C (2) with photonic mode 5.  \n\nWe wish to teleport an arbitrary input state |\u03c8\u27e9 on spin A to either B or C, but in a controlled superposition. We build an integrated photonic circuit that routes mode 3 equally into two Bell\u2010measurement blocks:\n  \u2013 Block 1 jointly measures modes (3 & 4) to teleport to B.\n  \u2013 Block 2 jointly measures modes (3 & 5) to teleport to C.\n\nA 50:50 directional coupler splits mode 3 into paths to both blocks; the two Bell\u2010analyzers are realized with beam splitters and phase shifters on chip. Each block has two ancilla detectors (modes 6,7 for B-branch and modes 8,9 for C-branch). A pair of clicks in either the B-branch detectors or the C-branch detectors heralds successful teleportation to B or C, respectively\u2014but because the split was coherent, the teleportation destination remains in superposition until detection. The final abstract mapping is:\n\n  |\u03c8\u27e9_A \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{B4} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9_{C5}\n    \u2192 ( |\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{6,7} + |\u03c8\u27e9_C\u2297|clicks\u27e9_{8,9} )\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\n\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21943)]  [S\u2082:(1\u21944)]  [S\u2083:(2\u21945)]  \ncircuit:    [split 3 \u2192 path to Bell-analyzer(3,4) + Bell-analyzer(3,5)]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2010read@0][spin\u2010read@1][spin\u2010read@2][anc6][anc7][anc8][anc9]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description       : \"On\u2010chip superposition\u2010of\u2010destinations quantum router via post\u2010selected teleportation\",\n  foldername        : \"quantum_router_teleport\",\n  edges_tried       : 30,\n  ftol              : 1e-06,\n  loss_func         : \"cr\",\n  num_anc           : 4,            # detectors 6,7,8,9\n  optimizer         : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples           : 12,\n  target_quantum    : [\"0B\",\"1B\",\"0C\",\"1C\"], # abstract mapping onto spin B or C\n  in_nodes          : [],\n  out_nodes         : [1,2,6,7,8,9], \n  single_emitters   : [],\n  amplitudes        : [],\n  removed_connections: [],          # allow all beam\u2010splitter couplings\n  anc_detectors     : [6,7,8,9],\n  number_resolving  : true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Can be extended to N output nodes by splitting into N Bell blocks.  \n  \u2013 Forms a building block for photonic\u2010mediated quantum networks on a chip: coherent routing primitives beyond fixed\u2010path swapping.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s dual\u2010destination teleportation switch in matter\u2010photonic form without adding a genuinely new element. Three coherent light\u2013matter interfaces produce three abstract Bell pairs:\n  \u2022 S\u2081: entangles qubit A (0) with photonic mode 3.  \n  \u2022 S\u2082: entangles qubit B (1) with photonic mode 4.  \n  \u2022 S\u2083: entangles qubit C (2) with photonic mode 5.  \n\nWe wish to teleport an unknown state |\u03c8\u27e9 from A into a coherent superposition of B and C. Two coherent light\u2013matter interfaces each generate a (noisy) abstract Bell pair:\n \u2022 S\u2081 produces entanglement between spin 0 and photon mode 2.  \n \u2022 S\u2082 produces entanglement between spin 1 and photon mode 3.  \n\nThese two raw spin\u2013photon Bell pairs suffer dephasing or imperfect fidelity. We wish to purify them into a single higher\u2010fidelity spin\u2013spin Bell pair on nodes 0&1. To do so, we interfere the two photons (modes 2,3) in an integrated parity\u2010check circuit: a 50:50 beam splitter plus phase shifter network that effectively implements a photonic parity measurement. Two number\u2010resolving detectors (modes 4 & 5) herald a successful even\u2010parity outcome. Conditioned on one click in each detector (post\u2010selection), the remaining spins collapse into a purified Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. This demonstrates on\u2010chip entanglement purification of matter qubit memories.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21942)]   [S\u2082:(1\u21943)]  \nparity\u2010circuit:  [BS(2,3) + phase network]  \ndetectors:   [spin-read@0][spin-read@1][anc@4][anc@5]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"On-chip entanglement purification of two spin qubits via photonic parity check\",\n  foldername          : \"spin_purification_chip\",\n  edges_tried         : 25,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 2,               # detectors 4 & 5\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 10,\n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],     # purified spin pair on nodes 0 & 1\n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [0,1],\n  single_emitters     : [],  \n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [4,5],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2013 Cascaded purification: chain multiple rounds by feeding in additional raw pairs.  \n \u2013 Multipartite purification: extend to three or more spins via multi-photon parity checks.  \n \u2013 Forms a building block for on-chip error mitigation in scalable photonic\u2013matter quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to known entanglement purification protocols (including on-chip qutrit purification and passive Bell-filter networks) and offers no fundamentally new element. The integrated photonic circuit implements the butterfly network coding: it combines photons 4 & 5 on a 50:50 coupler, splits outputs into two arms, and then each arm interferes with photon 6 or 7 in a Bell\u2010measurement block. A combined purification + swapping repeater segment: start with two noisy spin\u2013photon Bell\u2010pairs (A\u2013B and B\u2013C), first purify via a photonic parity check, then swap purified links to entangle A\u2013C\u2014all in one static integrated circuit.\n  Step 2: Assess novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    1. Too close to existing swap proposals.\n    2. Essentially two standard swaps in series.\n    3. The purification-swap repeater node is genuinely new for Pytheus: it fuses two network primitives (entanglement purification + swapping) into one passive circuit*, uses only pair sources, beam splitters, and heralding detectors, and no dynamic feedback.\n  Step 3: Pick idea (3).\n  Step 4: Novelty: No prior Pytheus target combines purification and entanglement swapping into a single static photonic circuit acting on matter\u2010qubit memories.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can encode four coherent light\u2013matter Bell-pair sources, a two-stage beam-splitter network (one parity\u2010check BS on the middle photonic modes, one Bell\u2010analyzer BS on the outer modes), and number-resolving detectors for post-selection.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014an on-chip \u201cpurification-swap repeater node\u201d that (i) purifies two imperfect spin\u2013photon Bell pairs at A\u2013B and B\u2013C, then (ii) swaps the purified entanglement to A\u2013C\u2014all implemented with coherent light\u2013matter interfaces and a static integrated photonic circuit:\n\nExplanation:\nWe have four stationary matter\u2010qubit nodes on chip:\n  \u2022 Q\u2081 (mode 0, \u201cA\u201d)  \n  \u2022 Q\u2082 (mode 1, first B qubit)  \n  \u2022 Q\u2083 (mode 2, second B qubit)  \n  \u2022 Q\u2084 (mode 3, \u201cC\u201d)\n\nFour coherent light\u2013matter Bell\u2010pair sources create two noisy Bell links:\n  \u2022 S\u2081 emits a (noisy) Bell pair between Q\u2081\u2194photon 4  \n  \u2022 S\u2082 emits a (noisy) Bell pair between Q\u2082\u2194photon 5  \n  \u2022 S\u2083 emits a (noisy) Bell pair between Q\u2083\u2194photon 6  \n  \u2022 S\u2084 emits a (noisy) Bell pair between Q\u2084\u2194photon 7  \n\nSequence of photonic operations (all on chip, no dynamic control):\n  1. Entanglement swapping on the purified outer photons (4 & 7):  \n     \u2013 They enter a standard linear-optics Bell\u2010state analyzer (BS + phase network).  \n     \u2013 Number\u2010resolving detectors ten (ancilla 10) & eleven (ancilla 11) herald a successful Bell outcome \u2192 remotely entangles Q\u2081 (A) and Q\u2084 (C) into a purified Bell pair.\n\nPost\u2010selection on clicks in ancilla detectors {8,9} and {10,11} yields a single high-fidelity Bell state between A and C.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:   [S\u2081:(0\u21944)] [S\u2082:(1\u21945)] [S\u2083:(2\u21946)] [S\u2084:(3\u21947)]  \ncircuit:    [BS(5,6)+phase \u2192 anc8,anc9]  \n            [BS(4,7)+phase \u2192 anc10,anc11]  \ndetectors:  [spin-read@0][spin-read@3][anc8][anc9][anc10][anc11]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"On-chip combined purification + swapping repeater node\",\n  foldername          : \"purify_swap_repeater\",\n  edges_tried         : 25,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 4,                # The \u201c\u2090\u201d outputs route to the Bell\u2010measurement block at intermediate node B, and the \u201c_b\u201d outputs route to the Bell\u2010measurement block at node C. Each Bell\u2010block is a standard linear\u2010optics Bell\u2010analyzer (50:50 BS + phases) acting on two photons:\n  \u2013 Block B measures (p\u2081\u2090,p\u2082\u2090) and (p\u2083\u2090,p\u2084\u2090), with ancilla detectors at modes 8,9,10,11.  \n  \u2013 Block C measures (p\u2081_b,p\u2082_b) and (p\u2083_b,p\u2084_b), with ancilla detectors at modes 12,13,14,15.\n\nBecause of the coherent splitting, the two possible swap\u2010paths (A\u2013B\u2013D via B or A\u2013C\u2013D via C) are in quantum superposition. A successful round of entanglement distribution is heralded by detecting one click\u2010pair in either Block B\u2019s ancillas or Block C\u2019s ancillas (post\u2010selection). Conditioned on that herald, spins A (0) and D (3) collapse into a Bell pair, demonstrating entanglement percolation with coherent multiplexing.\n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S\u2081:(0\u21944)]  [S\u2082:(1\u21945)]  [S\u2083:(2\u21946)]  [S\u2084:(3\u21947)]  \nsplitters:   [split 4\u21924\u2090,4_b; 5\u21925\u2090,5_b; 6\u21926\u2090,6_b; 7\u21927\u2090,7_b]  \nBell-blocks: [BS on (4\u2090,5\u2090) & (6\u2090,7\u2090) \u2192 anc8\u201311]  \n             [BS on (4_b,5_b) & (6_b,7_b) \u2192 anc12\u201315]  \ndetectors:   [spin-read@0][spin-read@1][spin-read@2][spin-read@3]\n             [anc8\u2026anc15]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"Coherent\u2010multiplexed entanglement percolation on a square network\",\n  foldername          : \"ent_percolation_multiplex\",\n  edges_tried         : 30,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 8,             # detectors 8\u201315\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 12,\n  target_quantum      : [\"00\",\"11\"],   # final Bell on Q_A(0) & Q_D(3)\n  in_nodes            : [],\n  out_nodes           : [0,3],\n  single_emitters     : [],\n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],\n  anc_detectors       : [8,9,10,11,12,13,14,15],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nKey Points:\n \u2022 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction is realized by the four spin\u2013photon Bell\u2010pair sources.  \n \u2022 Integrated photonic circuit implements passive 50:50 splitters and two Bell\u2010analyzer blocks\u2014no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.  \n \u2022 Heralding patterns in either Bell\u2010block enact entanglement swapping along one of two parallel routes; because of the initial splitting, the choice is in quantum superposition, showcasing coherent percolation.  \n \u2022 This protocol is readily generalizable to larger lattices (triangular, honeycomb) to study percolation thresholds, and to higher dimensions or multiplexed networks.\n\nThis target introduces a fundamentally new network transformation\u2014coherently multiplexed entanglement\u2010percolation\u2014bridging coherent light\u2013matter interfaces with integrated photonics in a Pytheus\u2010compatible experiment.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposal duplicates existing spatial-multiplexed swap protocols without adding a fundamentally new element.     "output": "Here is a concrete, Pytheus\u2010compatible proposal for a genuinely new network primitive that combines coherent light\u2013matter interfaces with an integrated photonic circuit\u2014and which is not mere state generation, but a nonlocal gate teleportation:\n\nOn-chip Heralded Remote CNOT Gate Between Two Spin Qubits\n\nExplanation:  \nWe label two stationary spin-qubit nodes on an integrated chip:  \n \u2022 Control qubit C at mode 0  \n \u2022 Target qubit T at mode 1  \n\nEach spin is interfaced to a flying photonic qubit via coherent light\u2013matter interaction:  \n \u2022 Bell\u2010pair source S_C emits an abstract \u2223\u03a6+\u27e9 between spin 0 and photonic mode 2.  \n \u2022 Bell\u2010pair source S_T emits an abstract \u2223\u03a6+\u27e9 between spin 1 and photonic mode 3.  \n\nWe wish to enact a nonlocal CNOT gate (control=C, target=T) purely by linear\u2010optics, ancillary photons and post\u2010selection\u2014no dynamic feed-forward. To do so:\n\n1. Inject two auxiliary single\u2010photon sources (modes 4 & 5) as the ancilla resource for the linear\u2010optics CNOT gadget.  \n2. Route the four photonic modes (2\u20135) through a fixed integrated circuit of beam splitters and phase shifters implementing the known post\u2010selected CNOT subroutine (e.g. the \u201c6-mode\u201d KLM gadget).  \n3. Place four number-resolving detectors on the ancilla output ports (modes 6\u20139).  \n4. Condition on the signature \u201cone click in each ancilla pair\u201d \u2013 this heralds a successful CNOT applied onto the remote spins.  \n\nAfter post-selection, the joint spin state at modes (0,1) has undergone the ideal CNOT transformation:  \n  \u2223c,t\u27e9\u2080\u2081  \u2192  \u2223c, t\u2295c\u27e9\u2080\u2081  \n\nVisualization (modes top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:    [S_C:(0\u21942)]   [S_T:(1\u21943)]   [ancilla 2\u21924][ancilla 3\u21925]  \ncircuit:     [linear-optics CNOT gadget routing 2\u20135 \u2192 detectors 6\u20139]  \ndetectors:   [spin-read@0][spin-read@1][anc@6][anc@7][anc@8][anc@9]\n\nSkeleton Pytheus config:\n{\n  description         : \"Heralded remote CNOT between two spin qubits via photonic CNOT gadget\",\n  foldername          : \"remote_CNOT_spin\",\n  edges_tried         : 25,\n  ftol                : 1e-06,\n  loss_func           : \"cr\",\n  num_anc             : 4,                # ancilla detectors 6\u20139\n  optimizer           : \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples             : 12,\n  target_quantum      : \"CNOT on qubits [0\u21921]\",  \n  in_nodes            : [],  \n  out_nodes           : [0,1],\n  single_emitters     : [2,3,4,5],        # modes 2&3 from Bell sources, 4&5 ancillas\n  amplitudes          : [],\n  removed_connections : [],  \n  anc_detectors       : [6,7,8,9],\n  number_resolving    : true\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel:  \nNo prior Pytheus target has implemented a fully remote, heralded two-qubit gate on matter qubits by using only on-chip coherent light\u2013matter pair sources and a passive integrated photonic CNOT gadget. This is a true network\u2010level transformation\u2014enacting a nonlocal CNOT\u2014rather than mere state generation.\n\nWhy it\u2019s feasible in Pytheus:  \n\u2022 Pytheus can encode the four single\u2010photon inputs (two from coherent spin\u2013photon Bell pairs, two ancillas) and search for a linear-optics circuit of beam splitters + phases that\u2014conditioned on fixed click patterns in four detectors\u2014implements the CNOT mapping on the two remaining (spin) modes.  \n\u2022 No dynamic feed-forward or cavities are required\u2014only probabilistic emitters, linear optical elements, and number\u2010resolving detection, all within Pytheus\u2019s capability.  \n\nGeneralizations:  \n\u2022 Remote CZ, SWAP or other entangling gates by swapping in different post-selected photonic subcircuits.  \n\u2022 Multi-qubit gate teleportation networks (Toffoli, Fredkin) across chains of spin memories.  \n\u2022 Building block for distributed photonic-spin quantum processors on a scalable integrated platform."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"coherent light matter interaction\" and \"integrated photonic circuit\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Successful BSM outcomes are heralded by two ancillary detectors (modes 4 & 5). Three coherent light\u2013matter interfaces produce abstract Bell pairs:\n \u2022 S\u2080 entangles Control(0) \u2194 photon p\u2080  \n \u2022 S\u2081 entangles A(1) \u2194 photon p\u2081  \n \u2022 S\u2082 entangles C(2) \u2194 photon p\u2082  \n\nGoal: entangle A and C via two successive Bell\u2010measurements on the photons, but with the order of those two measurements placed in quantum superposition\u2014i.e., realize a \u201cquantum switch\u201d of two swapping channels.  \n\nIntegrated circuit:\n \u2022 Photonic modes p\u2081 and p\u2082 pass through a 50:50 integrated splitter network controlled by p\u2080 (the control photon).  \n \u2022 Depending on the path in the splitter, p\u2081 first meets p\u2082 in Bell\u2010analyzer Module \u03b1 then Module \u03b2, or vice versa; because p\u2080 is in a superposition, the ordering of \u03b1 and \u03b2 is coherently superposed.  \n \u2022 Each Bell\u2010module is a beam splitter + phase\u2010shifter block with two ancilla detectors: Module \u03b1 \u2192 detectors d\u2083,d\u2084; Module \u03b2 \u2192 detectors d\u2085,d\u2086.  \n\nPost\u2010selection:\n \u2022 A click in one detector pair of \u03b1 and one of \u03b2 heralds a successful \u201cswitch\u2010ed\u201d entanglement\u2010swap.\n \u2022 Conditioned on these four clicks, spins A and C collapse into a Bell pair whose creation process had no definite order. Control qubit 0 remains entangled with which order \u201chappened,\u201d realizing the quantum\u2010switch resource state.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom):\nemitters:   [S\u2080:(0\u2194p\u2080)]  [S\u2081:(1\u2194p\u2081)]  [S\u2082:(2\u2194p\u2082)]  \ncircuit:    [p\u2081,p\u2082,p\u2080 \u2192 integrated MZI\u2013style split & two Bell\u2010modules \u03b1,\u03b2]  \ndetectors:  [spin\u2013read@0][spin\u2013read@1][spin\u2013read@2][d\u2083][d\u2084][d\u2085][d\u2086]\n\nKey points:\n \u2022 Coherent light\u2013matter interaction enters via the three Bell\u2010pair sources.  \n \u2022 Integrated photonic circuit implements a passive quantum switch\u2014indefinite order of two Bell\u2010measurements.  \n \u2022 Purely post-selected, no dynamic feedback.  \n \u2022 The abstract target is not a static many-qubit state, but the higher-order transformation (\u201csupermap\u201d) that superposes two network channels.  \n \u2022 This primitive can be generalized to superpositions of N different network topologies (e.g. parallel vs. series links) and opens a new class of on-chip quantum\u2010network operations beyond fixed paths.  \n\nThis proposal merges coherent spin\u2013photon interfaces with on-chip indefinite\u2010order photonic routing, offering a first demonstration of a quantum switch in a quantum\u2010network context.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is effectively identical to the ensemble\u2019s entanglement-switch quantum switch proposal. The \u201c\u2090\u201d outputs route to the Bell\u2010measurement block at intermediate node B, and the \u201c_b\u201d outputs route to the Bell\u2010measurement block at node C. Each Bell\u2010block is a standard linear\u2010optics Bell\u2010analyzer (50:50 BS + phases) acting on two photons:\n  \u2013 Block B measures (p\u2081\u2090,p\u2082\u2090) and (p\u2083\u2090,p\u2084\u2090), with ancilla detectors at modes 8,9,10,11.  \n  \u2013 Block C measures (p\u2081_b,p\u2082_b) and (p\u2083_b,p\u2084_b), with ancilla detectors at modes 12,13,14,15.\n\nBecause of the coherent splitting, the two possible swap\u2010paths (A\u2013B\u2013D via B or A\u2013C\u2013D via C) are in quantum superposition. A successful round of entanglement distribution is heralded by detecting one click\u2010pair in either Block B\u2019s ancillas or Block C\u2019s ancillas (post\u2010selection).
